snippet: When editing footage from two different camcorders, Final Cut gets a little kludgy. Fortunately, some varsity-level troubleshooting can provide a fix.
lead_paragraph: (Photo:  )   OK, this is going to be a really really geeky blog post, of interest only to a tiny number of video-editing types. But if it helps only one person out there well, then it really won't have been worthwhile. But still.  Remember when I wrote here, a couple of days ago, about how I attempted a "three-camera shoot" of my son's jazz-band concert? I used two hi-def Flip camcorders taped into place, plus a handheld Canon hi-def tape camcorder from my seat.  What I didn't tell you is how long it took me to edit the darned thing. Hours and hours. All week.  Final Cut, the editing software, was doing something I've never seen it do before: every time I adjusted a video clip's position in the timeline, the software had to "render" (process) that clip again, which meant my sitting there for several minutes until it was finished. (It never had to re-render the Flip clips-just the Canon clips.)  In the year I've been using Final Cut, I had never seen it do this; I figured it was related to my editing in high defintion.  But as the week wore on, I got so frustrated that I called Apple for tech support. I was advised to examine the file formats of my different clips. Turns out that the Flip clips came in the H.264 codec-and the Canon video was in the Apple Intermediate Codec (AIC). (Why? Because that's the format iMovie '09 creates when it imports hi-def video. I had used iMovie to import the Canon video because Final Cut, for some reason, could not "see" my camcorder.)  Final Cut conforms its timeline to the compression scheme of the *first* clip you drag into it-in this case, a Flip clip. That's why the Canon clips needed constant re-rendering; Final Cut had to keep converting them to the H.264 format for playback.  Now, it's easy to change the timeline format. I set it to AIC-and sure enough, I could now freely edit the Canon clips without ever waiting for re-rendering. Yay!  Except now the Flip clips had to re-render every time I touched them. Sigh.  The Apple guy suggested an ingenious solution: I could turn the Flip clips into AIC format behind Final Cut's back, without having to re-do their placement or editing.  He told me to right-click each of the two source Flip video clips (each 35 minutes long) and choose Make Offline. That detaches the video files on the hard drive from the Final Cut project.  Then, using QuickTime Player, I converted the two 35-minute Flip clips into the AIC format. Now the timeline, the Flip clips, and the Canon video would all have the same format. After that process, I did that right-clicking business and reconnected the converted offline Flip files.  My concern was that the Flip footage had been chopped up into hundreds of short, several-second clips, scattered all over the concert video-yet amazingly, when I reconnected the converted source files to my project, everything stayed exactly in place.  The only change, in fact, was that now, nothing needed rendering, ever!  I wound up finishing the project in about two hours. That work would have taken five times as long under the old scheme.  The Apple rep enjoyed troubleshooting this one. He explained that, in a way, I had come up with a bizarre between-two-worlds problem that most people never encounter: I had used the ultimate in cheap consumer cameras-those Flip camcorders-with the ultimate in high-end professional software.  I wish I'd discovered the incompatible-codec problem much, much earlier in the process-but I was thrilled to have solved it while there was still time to be saved.  OK, now I've got that off my chest. I'll return to less nerdy, jargony posts next week.
abstract: When editing footage from two different camcorders, Final Cut gets a little kludgy. Fortunately, some varsity-level troubleshooting can provide a fix.

headline.main: Camcorder Conflicts With Final Cut
headline.print_headline: Camcorder Conflicts With Final Cut

snippet: In its biggest sports installation to date, Sony is equipping the new Dallas Cowboys stadium with more than 3,000 LCD TVs.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever noticed that when most characters in feature films use computers, they're almost always using Macs? If you spent your whole life watching movies and never ventured outside, you could be forgiven for thinking that it was the Mac OS, not Windows, that had the dominant PC market share.  Of course that's not the case, but given that perception can alter reality, Apple believes that the money it costs to place its computers in front of the moviegoing public could well pay off in increased sales.  And that's the strategy behind Sony's move to put its LCD TVs in front of virtually every eyeball in the new Dallas Cowboys stadium that's opening in June. The electronics maker announced on Sunday that it had installed more than 3,000 flat-panel TVs throughout the venue, in luxury suites, concourses, as digital menus at the concession areas and elsewhere.  In addition to showing the latest hot dog prices, the displays, which range in size from 17 to 70 inches, will feature specially created high-definition programming about the game, including replays, interviews and other content.   Next up: Sony Blu-ray players and PlayStation consoles in the suites, allowing fans who have had enough of the game to watch a movie or play a video game.  This is Sony's largest sports stadium installation. In strategy, it is similar to the company's recently announced move to equip all Muvico theaters with LCD menu boards and PlayStation consoles. The aim in both cases: to make the Sony name synonymous with television.   After an early miscalculation at the beginning of the shift to flat-panel TVs when the company was hurt by too little product, the company hopes it can make up for lost time by creating the impression that the only TVs worth buying are Sonys.  Will it work for Sony? Did it work for Apple?
abstract: In its biggest sports installation to date, Sony is equipping the new Dallas Cowboys stadium with more than 3,000 LCD TVs.

headline.main: Are You Ready for Some Product Placement?
headline.print_headline: Are You Ready for Some Product Placement?

snippet: What Digital Rights Management is (or was) and how things are different for iTunes users now that it is gone.
lead_paragraph: What does it mean when iTunes music is "D.R.M.-free"? Does that mean I can play the files on other types of music players?  "D.R.M." stands for digital-rights management, which is the copy-protection software built into many songs purchased from the iTunes Store; tracks labeled "iTunes Plus" are free of it. Songs with D.R.M. can only be played on a certain number of computers and have other specified limits for use.  But earlier this year at the Macworld Expo, Apple announced that it was making all of the music in its iTunes Store D.R.M.-free over the next few months, which means there are no software restrictions on what you can do with a purchased song.  D.R.M.-free songs from the iTunes Store should play on other music players besides iPods and iPhones. Tracks from the iTunes Store are in the A.A.C. (Advanced Audio Coding) format. If the non-Apple music player cannot play A.A.C. files, you will have to convert the tracks to MP3.   You can actually do this right in iTunes: go to the iTunes preferences (found under the Edit menu in the Windows version and under the Application menu on the Mac) and click on the General tab. Click on the Import Settings button and change the import format to MP3. Then, select a track you want to convert in the iTunes library, right-click on it and choose "Create MP3 Version" from the menu. This makes a duplicate version in the MP3 format.  Although the copy-restrictions are gone, copyright law is still in effect. And another thing to remember before sharing iTunes music with the world at large: the name and e-mail address from the iTunes Store account used to buy a song are embedded in the purchased song file itself. You can see the information by selecting the track and pressing Control-I (Command-I on the Mac) and clicking on the Summary tab.
abstract: What Digital Rights Management is (or was) and how things are different for iTunes users now that it is gone.

headline.main: Q. & A. on New Music Rights in iTunes
headline.print_headline: Q & A: New Music Rights in iTunes

snippet: Apologies to the cynics, but we’re on a roll.
lead_paragraph: American style — basic American style, the American style that goes back to Henry Ford’s cars, James Dean’s T-shirt and the Timex watch — is not a pose but an adaptation to basic, fundamental challenges. Take jeans, our sartorial signature and our most influential contribution to the modern global wardrobe. They may sell for hundreds of dollars in swank boutiques from Boston to Buenos Aires, but it must be remembered that they originated as work wear for 19th-century laborers who valued them not for their color or silhouette but for their riveted ruggedness. Cowboy hats, truckers’ wallets, nylon windbreakers and Converse high-tops, to mention just a random sampling of the wearable artifacts that have come to define our nation’s aesthetic, were inspired by necessity rather than an intent to catch the eye. Design for design’s sake, our history suggests, is not an American priority. Instead, we design things to do a certain job (whether it’s in a mine, an office or a basketball arena), and when we devise a solution to the challenge, especially one that’s ingenious, simple or cheap, the result is a forward leap in style that may not even seem like one at first. (Until the Japanese trend scouts come along and hawk it in Tokyo department stores.)
abstract: Apologies to the cynics, but we’re on a roll.

headline.main: U.S.A. All the Way

snippet: A while back we wrote about Adeona, a free tracking program that could help police locate and recover a stolen laptop. As a bonus, we figured, thie...
lead_paragraph: A while back we wrote about Adeona, a free tracking program that could help police locate and recover a stolen laptop. As a bonus, we figured, thieves might be less inclined to steal any laptop, since every laptop they stole could potentially lead police to their doors. Enter Find My iPhone, a new service by Apple that does the same thing for your iPhone. After losing his phone in Chicago, one man recently tracked his phone down personally and confronted the thief, who, shocked at having been found, handed it back with a handshake.

snippet: There is something profoundly satisfying about putting in the extra effort out of love.
lead_paragraph: Tis the season of shortages. Eggo waffles are disappearing from supermarket shelves, the aftereffect of a flood at the manufacturing plant. Zhu Zhu Pets — those adorable robot hamsters — are the Tickle Me Elmos or Cabbage Patch dolls of 2009. And together these very different products reflect so much that is troubling, and reaffirming, about today’s parents.
abstract: There is something profoundly satisfying about putting in the extra effort out of love.

headline.main: Scrambling for Stuff to Show Love

snippet: If you watch a lot of television on Hulu.com and want to make it more like a media player and less of a Web browser experience, consider Hulu Desktop.
lead_paragraph: If you watch a lot of television on Hulu.com and want to make it more like a media player and less of a Web browser experience, consider Hulu Desktop. The free program, which works on Windows and Macintosh systems, presents the video in its own window and works with Windows Media Center or Apple’s remote controls. Hulu Desktop also offers easy ways to navigate the service, but it does require a computer with at lest two gigabytes of memory. The full specifications and the software are at hulu.com/labs.
abstract: If you watch a lot of television on Hulu.com and want to make it more like a media player and less of a Web browser experience, consider Hulu Desktop.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Hulu for Your Desktop

snippet: Billie Jean King answers readers’ questions.
lead_paragraph: Billie Jean King, who won 12 Grand Slam singles titles, including six at Wimbledon, responded to readers’ questions on Wednesday about Wimbledon and the world of tennis. King is the co-founder of World Team Tennis, which this summer will have a team playing in New York City for the first time in 30 years. In 1978, she played with the New York Apples; today, the team is called the NY Sportimes and is led by John McEnroe. It will play a seven-game home schedule in a new 2,000-seat stadium on Randalls Island starting July 7.
abstract: Billie Jean King answers readers’ questions.

snippet: As of this morning, Skype for iPhone is available as a free download at the iTunes App Store. Most of Skype’s original functionality — voice calls plus instant messaging — is there, but Voice Over Internet Protocol, or VOIP, calls can only be made...
lead_paragraph: By sheer coincidence, last Wednesday’s post, “Staying in Touch Internationally, on the Cheap,” came just as a flurry of Skype-related developments were about to hit the news cycle. On Sunday, a Times article by Brad Stone, outlined the Internet-telephone giant’s aggressive move from computers toward mobile devices. Soon, the article said, users of everything from the Blackberry to Google’s Android-based phones will be able to use Skype software and make calls at Skype’s reduced rates.
abstract: As of this morning, Skype for iPhone is available as a free download at the iTunes App Store. Most of Skype’s original functionality — voice calls plus instant messaging — is there, but Voice Over Internet Protocol, or VOIP, calls can only be made via Wi-Fi; Apple unfortunately prohibits them from its partners’ cellular data networks.

headline.main: Skype Midterm Report

snippet: Microsoft copies the iPhone with its new cellphone software, but it doesn’t copy Apple’s insistence on selling all the programs and music for its phones.

I was unimpressed with the new graphic flourishes that are the bulk of the changes. But the demo reminded me of some of the nicely open aspects of Microsoft’s approach that have always been there.
abstract: Microsoft copies the iPhone with its new cellphone software, but it doesn’t copy Apple’s insistence on selling all the programs and music for its phones.

snippet: Sutton Foster will trade her tiara for a nurse’s cap in the Encores! revival of “Anyone Can Whistle” at City Center this spring. Ms. Foster, below, who is currently playing Princess Fiona in the Broadway production of “Shrek the Musical,” will pla...
lead_paragraph: Sutton Foster will trade her tiara for a nurse’s cap in the Encores! revival of “Anyone Can Whistle” at City Center this spring. Ms. Foster, below, who is currently playing Princess Fiona in the Broadway production of “Shrek the Musical,” will play Nurse Fay Apple, a sanitarium manager skeptical of a dubious miracle in a fictional small town, a publicist for Encores! said Thursday in a news release. “Anyone Can Whistle,” the Arthur Laurents-Stephen Sondheim musical that had an abrupt nine-show run in 1964, will be performed at City Center from April 8 through April 11. A press representative for “Shrek” said Ms. Foster was under contract to that show through Jan. 24.

snippet: The 405 Chaise is one of the newest pieces from Loll Designs, a company that makes eco-friendly outdoor furniture and accessories.
lead_paragraph: The 405 Chaise is one of the newest pieces from Loll Designs, a Duluth, Minn., company that makes eco-friendly outdoor furniture and accessories out of recycled high density polyethylene, the material in No. 2 plastics. The 80-inch chaise, which comes in seven colors (black, white, chocolate, sand, leaf, sky and apple, above), requires little maintenance and will not fade, change color or warp, because of its material, according to the manufacturer. It has five settings  from an upright, suitable-for-reading position to completely flat  and a hidden shelf behind the seat that can be used to hold a book or sunscreen.
abstract: The 405 Chaise is one of the newest pieces from Loll Designs, a company that makes eco-friendly outdoor furniture and accessories.

snippet: How to commemorate MLK Day and the Presidential Inauguration with your children.
lead_paragraph: Odds are your children are home from school today. Odds are not quite as good, that you are, too. (About 31 percent of businesses are expected to give employees the day off.)   It is becoming traditional to commemorate Martin Luther King Day as a day of service, and this year the incoming President has particularly stressed that theme. So if you are home, and are looking for a way to better the world with your children, here are a few suggestions.   Examiner.com has culled a list of children's service events, all in the New York area:     Martin Luther King, Jr. Day Celebration_Jewish Community Center 334 Amsterdam Ave. (at 76th St) Upper West Side When: MLK Jr. Day, Monday 11am–2pm   Description: Today is all about bettering the community with your tots. At the JCC, families can create welcome kits for children coming into hospitals as part of the Camp Sunshine project, as well as prepare meals that will be delivered to local shelters. To round out the event, kids can write letters to President-Elect Obama on the eve of the historic inauguration. All ages.  Children for Children: 7th Annual Grow Involved on MLK Jr. Day At 2 locations: Harlem / Wash. Heights 176 East 115th St. 122 Amsterdam Ave. When: MLK Jr. Day, Monday 10am–2pm .  Description: Stop by either location between 10 a.m. and 2 p.m. to join thousands of children and adults in celebration of Dr. King's famous words, "Everybody can be great because everybody can serve." Last year, more than 2,000 volunteers came together for this event and we look forward to another momentous day this year. Participants will have the chance to complete a wide variety of hands-on projects, benefiting many different New York City-based and international causes.  Green Apple Corps Seward Park, East Broadway and Essex St. in Lower East Side/Chinatown When: MLK Jr. Day, Monday 9:00am–2:45pm; feel free to show up at any time   Description: Green Apple Corps will host a special Day of Service at Seward Park, to celebrate MLK's legacy and participate in urban environmental stewardship. Students and families are welcome to participate! Activities include street tree pit care, mulching and composting, nature tours around Seward Park, and environmental education with the Urban Park Rangers and Green Apple Corps.  Hundreds more possibilities, across the country, can be found on my.mlkday.gov and USAservice.org. Both sites turned up several dozen events within a 25 mile radius of my house.   Some schools, though not many businesses, are also closed for the inauguration tomorrow. Whether your children have school or not, you can celebrate history with them tonight, at the Kids Inaugural, which will be hosted by Michelle Obama and Jill Biden and feature Sasha and Malia's favorites – the Jonas Brothers – among others. You don't have to go to Washington (where there are no more tickets available.) You can watch it on the Disney Channel.   If you are looking for facts and folklore to go with your pop-singers, check out "Our White House Inauguaration Celebration Kit!" created by the National Children's Book and Literacy Alliance. There you will find everything you might ever want to know about Inaugural history, on variety of school-age reading levels.  I have been hearing from parents in recent weeks who are considering taking their kids out of class, maybe just during lunchtime (or, on the West coast, for a late breakfast…) so the family can watch the event, which starts at 11:30 EST, together. As it happens, my boys are off from school, for Superintendent's Day, and we'll be hanging on our couch together, which is where we found ourselves often this past year – watching Presidential debates, or waiting for primary, and then general, election night returns.   What are you doing with your children today? What will you be doing with your children tomorrow? And what do you hope they are learning while you do it?
abstract: How to commemorate MLK Day and the Presidential Inauguration with your children.

headline.main: Holiday as History Lesson
headline.print_headline: Taking kids out of school for history?

snippet: Off of today's Apple press conference in California: What Apple features will be added to the iPhone later this summer.
lead_paragraph: Happy St. Patrick's Day! If you're not wearing green, it may be enough just to be green with envy—for the iPhone software programmers who got access today to the beta version of the iPhone 3.0 software. Apple unveiled it in California today.   The rest of us will get the goodies in the form of a free software update this summer. With only a couple of technical exceptions, all of the new features will work on all iPhones and iPod Touches ever made, so nobody will be left behind. Nice.   And what are the new features?   * Cut, Copy, and Paste. Double-tap/drag some text to highlight it. A balloon offering Cut and Copy buttons appears at your fingertip. (Drag either end of the highlighted region to extend it.) Double-tap somewhere else—even a different program—to paste what you've copied. To undo a paste, just shake the iPhone.   * Big keyboard everywhere. Used to be, you could rotate the iPhone to landscape orientation, which made the keyboard keys much bigger and better spaced—easier for typing—but only in the Safari Web browser. Now you can get the big keyboard in all core iPhone programs: Notes, Mail, and so on.   * Bluetooth stereo audio. The iPhone can now play your music to so-called A2DP wireless Bluetooth headphones. They sound amazing. (Not available to first-generation iPhones.)   * MMS messaging. Now you can send pictures or audio clips to other cellphones, just as on any other mobile phone on earth. You can also send contacts from your address book (vCards), or your location information, in the same way. (Not available to first-generation iPhones.)   * Spotlight. There's a new search screen to the "left" of your first Home page (swipe your finger to see it). It lets you search your entire iPhone, including your list of programs—and since you can open a program from the results list, it's now a speedy launcher. No more swiping through 9 screens full of icons just to find the one you want.   You can also search your address book, your e-mail stash (hurrah!), your iPod song and video lists, your calendar, and your notes.   * Audio recording and trimming. Record notes to self, interviews, and so on—then edit and send to another cellphone, if you like.   * Subscribed calendars. The iPhone calendar can now subscribe to published shared calendars (like sports-league schedules) in CalDAV or .ics formats.    Another big category of enhancements aren't iPhone features per se, but are potential features available to iPhone software programmers. For example:   * Push notifications. The iPhone still can't run more than one program simultaneously (that feature kills battery life, says Apple). But at least now, chat programs (for example) can notify you when people are trying to contact you, even if those programs aren't running at the moment, thanks to "push" notifications.   * In-app purchases. Now you'll be able to buy new issues of a magazine, new e-books inside a reader program, additional game levels, and so on, right from within the program itself. You don't have to lumber off to the App Store to get them.   * Peer-to-peer recognition. iPhones can discover and connect to other iPhones nearby. Great for playing games against friends, or for shooting e-business cards to other people.   * Turn-by-turn directions. Programmers can now create GPS programs with turn-by-turn directions—as long as they don't use Google's wonderful map information. Thanks to some dumb legal restrictions, they have to supply their own map data.   So basically, Apple seems to have addressed almost all of the chronic complaints about the iPhone's core features—just in time for the arrival of the iPhone's first serious competition this summer. You gotta love competition, eh?
abstract: Off of today's Apple press conference in California: What Apple features will be added to the iPhone later this summer.

headline.main: Pogue's Quick Take on iPhone OS 3.0
headline.print_headline: Pogue's Quick Take on iPhone OS 3.0

snippet: The Element by Fuego barbecue has a stainless steel body and cast iron grilling surface in a modest size.
lead_paragraph: The Element by Fuego barbecue is a scaled-down version of the Fuego 01, the $3,500 minimalist grill introduced in 2006. Created by the same designer  Robert Brunner, a former industrial designer for Apple  it has a stainless steel body and cast iron grilling surface like the original, but a more modest size (only 27 inches wide, instead of 45) and price (about $600, or $400 in the powder-coated finish). A single knob controls the dual-zone gas burners for direct or indirect cooking; the enamel lid turns it into a convection roasting oven, and other tops can be purchased to convert it into a pizza oven ($79) or a griddle ($129). Available in May; for information or to order: (888) 883-8346 or elementbyfuego.com.
abstract: The Element by Fuego barbecue has a stainless steel body and cast iron grilling surface in a modest size.

headline.main: An Even More Minimalist Grill

Created by the same designer  Robert Brunner, a former industrial designer for Apple  it has a stainless steel body and cast iron grilling surface like the original, but a more modest size (only 27 inches wide, instead of 45) and price (about $600, or $400 in the powder-coated finish). Available in May; for information or to order: (888) 883-8346 or elementbyfuego.com.
abstract: The Element by Fuego barbecue has a stainless steel body and cast iron grilling surface in a modest size.

snippet: How to commemorate MLK Day and the Presidential Inauguration with your children.
lead_paragraph: Odds are your children are home from school today. Odds are not quite as good, that you are, too. (About 31 percent of businesses are expected to give employees the day off.)   It is becoming traditional to commemorate Martin Luther King Day as a day of service, and this year the incoming President has particularly stressed that theme. So if you are home, and are looking for a way to better the world with your children, here are a few suggestions.   Examiner.com has culled a list of children's service events, all in the New York area:     Martin Luther King, Jr. Day Celebration_Jewish Community Center 334 Amsterdam Ave. (at 76th St) Upper West Side When: MLK Jr. Day, Monday 11am–2pm   Description: Today is all about bettering the community with your tots. At the JCC, families can create welcome kits for children coming into hospitals as part of the Camp Sunshine project, as well as prepare meals that will be delivered to local shelters. To round out the event, kids can write letters to President-Elect Obama on the eve of the historic inauguration. All ages.  Children for Children: 7th Annual Grow Involved on MLK Jr. Day At 2 locations: Harlem / Wash. Heights 176 East 115th St. 122 Amsterdam Ave. When: MLK Jr. Day, Monday 10am–2pm .  Description: Stop by either location between 10 a.m. and 2 p.m. to join thousands of children and adults in celebration of Dr. King's famous words, "Everybody can be great because everybody can serve." Last year, more than 2,000 volunteers came together for this event and we look forward to another momentous day this year. Participants will have the chance to complete a wide variety of hands-on projects, benefiting many different New York City-based and international causes.  Green Apple Corps Seward Park, East Broadway and Essex St. in Lower East Side/Chinatown When: MLK Jr. Day, Monday 9:00am–2:45pm; feel free to show up at any time   Description: Green Apple Corps will host a special Day of Service at Seward Park, to celebrate MLK's legacy and participate in urban environmental stewardship. Students and families are welcome to participate! Activities include street tree pit care, mulching and composting, nature tours around Seward Park, and environmental education with the Urban Park Rangers and Green Apple Corps.  Hundreds more possibilities, across the country, can be found on my.mlkday.gov and USAservice.org. Both sites turned up several dozen events within a 25 mile radius of my house.   Some schools, though not many businesses, are also closed for the inauguration tomorrow. Whether your children have school or not, you can celebrate history with them tonight, at the Kids Inaugural, which will be hosted by Michelle Obama and Jill Biden and feature Sasha and Malia's favorites – the Jonas Brothers – among others. You don't have to go to Washington (where there are no more tickets available.) You can watch it on the Disney Channel.   If you are looking for facts and folklore to go with your pop-singers, check out "Our White House Inauguaration Celebration Kit!" created by the National Children's Book and Literacy Alliance. There you will find everything you might ever want to know about Inaugural history, on variety of school-age reading levels.  I have been hearing from parents in recent weeks who are considering taking their kids out of class, maybe just during lunchtime (or, on the West coast, for a late breakfast…) so the family can watch the event, which starts at 11:30 EST, together. As it happens, my boys are off from school, for Superintendent's Day, and we'll be hanging on our couch together, which is where we found ourselves often this past year – watching Presidential debates, or waiting for primary, and then general, election night returns.   What are you doing with your children today? What will you be doing with your children tomorrow? And what do you hope they are learning while you do it?
abstract: How to commemorate MLK Day and the Presidential Inauguration with your children.

headline.main: Holiday as History Lesson
headline.print_headline: Taking kids out of school for history?

snippet: A German PC maker, HyperMegaNet, has joined Psystar of the United States in marketing cheap, ugly -- and unauthorized -- Macintosh clones.
lead_paragraph: From our colleagues at Gadgetwise:  In 1984, I was all set to buy my first computer: a Kaypro 4. It came complete with Wordstar, dBase II, MicroPlan, Microsoft Basic, S-Basic, SuperCalc, and the CP/M operating system.  It also had all the design charm of an empty gasoline can.  That's one of the reasons I opted instead to make the first Macintosh my first computer. Not only was I enthralled with the graphical user interface, but, for its time, the computer actually looked good; it was typically described as "cute."  Which is one reason that Apple has little to fear from the two companies that are currently selling unauthorized clones that run Mac OS X: Psystar in the United States, and HyperMegaNet, a newcomer from Wolfsburg, Germany. Read more...
abstract: A German PC maker, HyperMegaNet, has joined Psystar of the United States in marketing cheap, ugly -- and unauthorized -- Macintosh clones.

headline.main: Macintosh Clones: Cheap but Ugly
headline.print_headline: Macintosh Clones: Cheap but Ugly

snippet: Spurred, perhaps, by the New York Philharmonic’s embrace of the iPhone, Christie’s has become the latest cultural institution to offer its own dedicated application for the Apple mobile device, Reuters reported. On Wednesday the auction house said...
lead_paragraph: Spurred, perhaps, by the New York Philharmonic’s embrace of the iPhone, Christie’s has become the latest cultural institution to offer its own dedicated application for the Apple mobile device, Reuters reported. On Wednesday the auction house said that its free application, available at the iTunes App Store, at Christies.com and through Facebook and Twitter, would offer access to its sales calendar and allow users to browse more than 450 auctions in over 80 categories including fine and decorative arts, jewelry, photographs, collectibles and wine. The application also offers detailed lot information and the ability to zoom in on images of offerings, as well as the all-important feature of e-mailing lots to friends. Christie’s told Reuters that it hoped to add a live-bidding component to the application.

snippet: Gizmodo Gallery open reveals a future with some news wrinkles and a few kinks.
lead_paragraph: Nothing, they say, ages faster than the future, a meme that has persisted ever since there was one. Decoder thought we'd check out the theory at the opening of the Gizmodo Gallery last night, which was held so far downtown that we needed a hipster app on our iPhone to find it. Kidding, the temporary gallery (now open to the public) is just below Houston in Manhattan at 267 Elizabeth Street -- we counted three colleagues from the House of Many Doors, so how hip could it really be? -- and was jammed to the brim with all manner of needless, heedless, and yes, potentially useful electronic tchotchkes, many of which are apparently sucking the juice out of the grid.

snippet: Michael Goldstein’s roof garden in SoHo could easily be mistaken for a suburban backyard, but after a citation from the city, the building’s owner wants it removed.
lead_paragraph: Close to 40 years ago, Michael Goldstein, then a young dad, rented the top floor of a building on the corner of Broome and Mercer Streets, and plunked a sandbox and kiddie pool on the roof. Such was the humble beginning of what would eventually become an elaborate, fantasyland garden, complete with convincing-looking synthetic grass, peach, apple and cherry trees, blueberry bushes, and Adirondack chairs nestled among the fragrant boughs.

snippet: The auction house said that its free application would offer access to its sales calendar and allow users to browse over 450 auctions in over 80 categories.
lead_paragraph: Spurred, no doubt, by the New York Philharmonic’s embrace of the iPhone, Christie’s has become the latest cultural institution to offer its own dedicated application for the Apple mobile device, Reuters reported. On Wednesday, the auction house said that its free application, available at the iTunes App Store and the Christies.com Web site and through Facebook and Twitter, would offer access to its sales calendar and allow users to browse more than 450 auctions in over 80 categories including fine and decorative arts, jewelry, photographs, collectibles and wine. The application also offers detailed lot information and the ability to zoom in on images of offerings, as well as the all-important feature of e-mailing lots to friends. Christie’s told Reuters that it hoped to add a live-bidding component to the application.
abstract: The auction house said that its free application would offer access to its sales calendar and allow users to browse over 450 auctions in over 80 categories.

headline.main: Christie’s Offers Its Own iPhone App

snippet: An independent publisher says it is negotiating to release Herman Rosenblat’s falsified memoir “Angel at the Fence” as a work of fiction.
lead_paragraph: Days after Berkley Books announced that it was canceling the publication of Herman Rosenblat’s memoir “Angel at the Fence” following the author’s acknowledgment that he had falsified parts of his story, an independent publisher said it is negotiating to release the book as a work of fiction based on a screenplay adapted from the book. In the memoir, Mr. Rosenblat wrote that he met his future wife during the Holocaust, when he was a prisoner at a concentration camp and she would throw him apples from outside the camp. The book was canceled after scholars disputed the truth of that and other details. But York House Press, a publisher based in White Plains, said it was in discussions to release the book as a work of fiction called “Flower at the Fence.” In a statement on its Web site, York House Press said, “We believe Mr. Rosenblat’s motivations were very human, understandable and forgivable.”
abstract: An independent publisher says it is negotiating to release Herman Rosenblat’s falsified memoir “Angel at the Fence” as a work of fiction.

headline.main: Disputed Memoir May Be Published as Fiction

snippet: The founder of a distillery in Oregon on how his life in local agriculture shaped his approach to making spirits.
lead_paragraph: I grew up in Roseburg, Ore., pop. 4500, before TV came to town and before I-5 was built. Portland was four hours away on a two-lane road in a station wagon with four brothers.   Roseburg had an active agricultural economy, with lots of fruit and vegetables, some livestock (mostly sheep, I think) and turkeys, and the remains of a prune industry in the form of "prune dryers," tall, oddly shaped barn-like structures that had heaters that dried the Italian Blue Plum into prunes. We also had a built-in cultural bias against anything that was grown or made locally. People that went West in the dust bowl years, picked crops in California in the depression, and worked in the Oakland shipyards in World War II came to southern Oregon in the late '40s to find work logging the native forests. I believe they didn't "think local" because they were not sure where they were. Several good local cheese makers gave up in the '50s or early '60s. (Anyone remember Langlois cheese?) There was a terrific melon from Dillard, Ore., an elegant cantaloupe from an ideal microclimate. We grew terrific pole beans, good strawberries and very good walnuts. I don't think much of that is left.   I set out to rescue the Bartlett pear market, provide myself with a decent supply of poire williams, and maybe make a buck or two.   Another branch of my family had been growing apples and pears in the Hood River Valley in Northern Oregon since 1909. The family lost the orchards in the Great Depression, and maybe another time, depending on how my mother wants to spin the legend. After World War II my dad started buying back the old orchard property, although the original orchards were pretty much gone. In the 1970s we started buying other nearby orchards, and we have been buying in small and large batches, ever since.  I pretty much stayed out of farming and ran the industrial side of the family. My dad had a small company making hunting and shooting accessories. He wanted out, and sold it to me for a dollar down and a dollar a week. It worked out well, I made two or three good decisions and it grew like crazy. And so I thought I was hot stuff, a marketing genius. I was unimpressed by what I saw of fruit marketing. Or fruit growing, for that matter. The local fruit growers were pretty well wedded to chemicals, and odd varieties of apples and pears were being driven out by an industry devotion to the Red Delicious apple. And of course, if you went to a local grocery, even in the fall harvest season, the fruit you encountered was right off a truck that had come from a warehouse a hundred miles away. Small fruit growing regions — and Hood River Valley at 15,000 acres of orchards was very small — had a hard time attracting capital and management and marketing talent to compete here in America, let alone in the world market.  The other thing I should mention is that it was my good fortune to spend a lot of time in Europe, starting in 1960. There, I developed an interest in good French regional wine, which led to an interest in almost any wine from Europe, and that led to an interest in everything else from Europe that I could eat or drink. Eventually I came to appreciate that the people I met ate and drank only what they grew — what they had. Their genius was taking whatever they could grow and making something wonderful out of it. Poor land that could only support goats led to chevre. Undrinkable ugni blanc wine led to cognac. Small, crummy apples in Normandy led to Calvados. And so on.   Eventually I learned that the Williams pear, which the French, Swiss and Germans made into the fantastic Williams pear schnapps, or eau de vie of poire williams, was the same as our Bartlett pear. (Photo: (David Karp for The New York Times) A Bartlett pear.) The Bartlett pear was the principal ingredient of fruit cocktail, which my generation back home had been raised on. But as the fruit cocktail died a well-earned death, the market for the Bartlett pear swooned. And that's how I got into trouble. I came home and set out to rescue the Bartlett pear market, save orchard farmland from development for tract homes, provide myself with a decent supply of good poire williams, which was impossible to get in Oregon at that time, and maybe make a buck or two.   I did most of it. I started with an empty warehouse in an old industrial neighborhood in Northwest Portland. My hope was that inasmuch at the Bartlett and Williams pears are the same, and the still I bought was the genuine European item, and the techniques were simple, that I could eventually learn how to make good poire williams.   I expected it would take years to get something I could take to market. But my first still load, in the fall of 1985, was good. That first taste was good. Pear growing, pear ripening, pear crushing, pear fermentation and pear distillation seemed almost intuitive. We had a lot to learn, of course. There is a difference between making 500 gallons of pear mash, and making 60,000 gallons. Last year alone, my distillery bought 500,000 pounds of Oregon pears.   And Roseburg, where I grew up and which I left decades ago, is now a hotbed of imaginative, innovative winemaking. No longer just poison oak, sheep and scrub oak grow in those valleys and on those pretty hills. Rows of hot weather grape varietals miraculously correct for the microclimate produce fruit that produces unusual and wonderful wines. The scrub oak, actually Oregon White Oak, or quercus garryana, is now made into barrels for aging wine and whiskey. An hour south, Rogue Creamery Blue Cheese is made and sold, and they can't make enough each year. I don't know if the Dillard melons are back, and I know the pole beans are not, but now even modest restaurants in Roseburg proudly list "local" cheese and "local" wine. A huge cultural change has taken place.
abstract: The founder of a distillery in Oregon on how his life in local agriculture shaped his approach to making spirits.

headline.main: A Perfect Pear
headline.print_headline: A Perfect Pear

snippet: Oprah.com, the Web site of “The Oprah Winfrey Show,” has posted a disclaimer acknowledging that Herman Rosenblat admitted he had invented portions of his Holocaust memoir.
lead_paragraph: Oprah.com, the Web site of “The Oprah Winfrey Show,” has posted a disclaimer acknowledging that Herman Rosenblat admitted he had invented portions of his Holocaust memoir. “Based on this admission,” the disclaimer said, “the publisher of his forthcoming memoir ‘Angel at the Fence’ canceled plans to print his book.” In “Angel at the Fence,” which was canceled by Berkley Books, Mr. Rosenblat wrote that while he was a prisoner at a concentration camp in Germany he met his future wife at its fence, where she would throw apples to him from the outside; this claim was later disputed by scholars who said the layout of the camp would have prevented this. Ms. Winfrey featured Mr. Rosenblat on her show, calling his tale “the single greatest love story, in 22 years of doing this show, we’ve ever told on the air.” She has not commented publicly on the cancellation.
abstract: Oprah.com, the Web site of “The Oprah Winfrey Show,” has posted a disclaimer acknowledging that Herman Rosenblat admitted he had invented portions of his Holocaust memoir.

headline.main: Winfrey Web Site Notes Fabricated Memoir
headline.print_headline: Winfrey Web Site Notes Fabricated Memoir

snippet: Are concerns about increased costs to business well founded? Or has a tipping point been reached?.
lead_paragraph: A wave of defections from the United States Chamber of Commerce continued last week when Exelon, one of the country's largest utilities, announced its departure. John W. Rowe, the utility's chief executive, said Exelon was leaving because of the chamber's "stridency against carbon legislation." The chamber has recently opposed an Environmental Protection Agency proposal to use the Clear Air Act to set limits on greenhouse gases. In addition, chamber officials have been quoted calling for a "Scopes monkey trial" about the science of climate change. The chamber, which recently clarified its position on climate policy, says it is concerned that measures intended to address global warming will raise costs for business.
abstract: Are concerns about increased costs to business well founded? Or has a tipping point been reached?.

headline.main: Is the Chamber of Commerce Right About Climate Change?

snippet: The elegant, whimsical and sometimes haunting bronze sculptures by the French artists Claude and Francois-Xavier Lalanne are the latest addition to the ongoing outdoor sculpture program on Park Avenue.
lead_paragraph: The elegant, whimsical and sometimes haunting bronze sculptures by the French artists Claude and Francois-Xavier Lalanne are the latest addition to the ongoing outdoor sculpture program on Park Avenue. Beginning Sept. 13, eight Lalanne sculptures will grace the avenue's median until Nov. 20, in an exhibition sponsored by the New York City Parks Public Art Program in conjunction with the Paul Kasmin Gallery and in cooperation with the Park Avenue Sculpture Committee. This is the first major outdoor show of the Lalannes' work (Francois-Xavier died last year), which is collected by design-world luminaries like Jacques Grange and Reed Krakoff. The sculptures, which will be installed between 52nd and 57th Streets, include some of the artists' best-known pieces, including a flock of Francois-Xavier's famous sheep and Claude's "Choupatte," a anthropomorphized bronze cabbage standing on bird legs, as well as her "Pomme de New York," a really big apple.
abstract: The elegant, whimsical and sometimes haunting bronze sculptures by the French artists Claude and Francois-Xavier Lalanne are the latest addition to the ongoing outdoor sculpture program on Park Avenue.

headline.main: Lalanne | Sculpture Park (Avenue)
headline.print_headline: Lalanne | Sculpture Park (Avenue)

snippet: London is known for top-quality design exhibitions, and this season doesn’t disappoint. Opening Nov. 18 at the Design Museum is a retrospective of the work of the German designer Dieter Rams, including his pioneering electronics designs for Braun,...
lead_paragraph: London is known for top-quality design exhibitions, and this season doesn’t disappoint. Opening Nov. 18 at the Design Museum is a retrospective of the work of the German designer Dieter Rams, including his pioneering electronics designs for Braun, without which there might be no iPod (Apple’s Jonathan Ive is one of five designers who are interviewed for the show), and those for the furniture company Vitsoe. On Nov. 26, the Serpentine Gallery opens its first-ever contemporary design exhibition, “Design Real,” curated by the German industrial designer Konstantin Grcic. His selection focuses on objects (like Carlotta de Bevilacqua’s Yang light for Artemide, below right) that have a practical function, are accessible to all and have made a significant impact on the world. Grcic’s own work will be the subject of “Konstantin Grcic: Decisive Design,” starting Nov. 20 at the Art Institute of Chicago. [?][?][?] PILAR VILADAS
abstract: London is known for top-quality design exhibitions, and this season doesn’t disappoint. Opening Nov. 18 at the Design Museum is a retrospective of the work of the German designer Dieter Rams, including his pioneering electronics designs for Braun, without which there might be no iPod (Apple’s Jonathan Ive is one of five designers who are interviewed for the show), and those for the furniture company Vitsoe. On Nov. 26, the Serpentine Gallery opens its first-ever contemporary design exhibition, “Design Real,” curated by the German industrial designer Konstantin Grcic. His selection focuses on objects (like Carlotta de Bevilacqua’s Yang light for Artemide, below right) that have a practical function, are accessible to all and have made a significant impact on the world. Grcic’s own work will be the subject of “Konstantin Grcic: Decisive Design,” starting Nov. 20 at the Art Institute of Chicago. [?][?][?] PILAR VILADAS.

snippet: Are concerns about increased costs to business well founded? Or has a tipping point been reached?.
lead_paragraph: A wave of defections from the United States Chamber of Commerce continued last week when Exelon, one of the country's largest utilities, announced its departure. John W. Rowe, the utility's chief executive, said Exelon was leaving because of the chamber's "stridency against carbon legislation." The chamber has recently opposed an Environmental Protection Agency proposal to use the Clear Air Act to set limits on greenhouse gases. In addition, chamber officials have been quoted calling for a "Scopes monkey trial" about the science of climate change. The chamber, which recently clarified its position on climate policy, says it is concerned that measures intended to address global warming will raise costs for business.
abstract: Are concerns about increased costs to business well founded? Or has a tipping point been reached?.

headline.main: Is the Chamber of Commerce Right About Climate Change?

snippet: The elegant, whimsical and sometimes haunting bronze sculptures by the French artists Claude and Francois-Xavier Lalanne are the latest addition to the ongoing outdoor sculpture program on Park Avenue.
lead_paragraph: The elegant, whimsical and sometimes haunting bronze sculptures by the French artists Claude and Francois-Xavier Lalanne are the latest addition to the ongoing outdoor sculpture program on Park Avenue. Beginning Sept. 13, eight Lalanne sculptures will grace the avenue's median until Nov. 20, in an exhibition sponsored by the New York City Parks Public Art Program in conjunction with the Paul Kasmin Gallery and in cooperation with the Park Avenue Sculpture Committee. This is the first major outdoor show of the Lalannes' work (Francois-Xavier died last year), which is collected by design-world luminaries like Jacques Grange and Reed Krakoff. The sculptures, which will be installed between 52nd and 57th Streets, include some of the artists' best-known pieces, including a flock of Francois-Xavier's famous sheep and Claude's "Choupatte," a anthropomorphized bronze cabbage standing on bird legs, as well as her "Pomme de New York," a really big apple.
abstract: The elegant, whimsical and sometimes haunting bronze sculptures by the French artists Claude and Francois-Xavier Lalanne are the latest addition to the ongoing outdoor sculpture program on Park Avenue.

snippet: Accenture, the technology consulting firm, agreed to buy a Nokia business that advises and provides services for cellphone makers using the Symbian operating system, the companies said Friday.
lead_paragraph: Accenture, the technology consulting firm, agreed to buy a Nokia business that advises and provides services for cellphone makers using the Symbian operating system, the companies said Friday. The unit helps phone manufacturers make the operating system work with their products, and aids chip makers and carriers. Terms were not disclosed. The deal adds 165 employees to Accenture’s organization and lets the company expand a business that provides consulting services related to mobile operating systems. Symbian is the world’s most popular software running more advanced cellphones, and is used on more than 250 million handsets.

snippet: Oprah.com, the Web site of “The Oprah Winfrey Show,” has posted a disclaimer acknowledging that Herman Rosenblat admitted he had invented portions of his Holocaust memoir.
lead_paragraph: Oprah.com, the Web site of “The Oprah Winfrey Show,” has posted a disclaimer acknowledging that Herman Rosenblat admitted he had invented portions of his Holocaust memoir. “Based on this admission,” the disclaimer said, “the publisher of his forthcoming memoir ‘Angel at the Fence’ canceled plans to print his book.” In “Angel at the Fence,” which was canceled by Berkley Books, Mr. Rosenblat wrote that while he was a prisoner at a concentration camp in Germany he met his future wife at its fence, where she would throw apples to him from the outside; this claim was later disputed by scholars who said the layout of the camp would have prevented this. Ms. Winfrey featured Mr. Rosenblat on her show, calling his tale “the single greatest love story, in 22 years of doing this show, we’ve ever told on the air.” She has not commented publicly on the cancellation.
abstract: Oprah.com, the Web site of “The Oprah Winfrey Show,” has posted a disclaimer acknowledging that Herman Rosenblat admitted he had invented portions of his Holocaust memoir.

snippet: Arthur Rock, who backed Fairchild Semiconductor, Intel and Apple, invested with Bernard L. Madoff, according to a list made public in bankruptcy court filings Thursday.
lead_paragraph: One of Silicon Valley's legends, Arthur Rock, invested with Bernard L. Madoff, according to the customer list made public Wednesday in bankruptcy court filings.   Mr. Rock, one of the founding fathers of venture capital, invested with Mr. Madoff through five trusts, according to the list.   Mr. Rock helped found and finance Fairchild Semiconductor. As a venture capitalist with Davis & Rock and later Arthur Rock & Company, he financed Apple and Intel in their early days. In 2008, Mr. Rock's net worth was $1.1 billion, making him No. 1,014 on the list of the richest people in the world, according to Forbes.   A few important caveats: there is no way to tell from the list whether Mr. Rock and other investors were victims of Mr. Madoff's reputed $50 billion Ponzi scheme or customers of his legitimate broker-dealer operation. Additionally, some people on the list may be trustees for accounts opened for other people.   Mr. Rock was unavailable to comment and the person who answered the phone at his office could not confirm whether Mr. Rock invested with Mr. Madoff, though his office address matches the address in the filing.   In 1957, when Mr. Rock was working as an investment banker at Hayden Stone, a New York firm, he heard from a group of eight scientists at Shockley Semiconductor Laboratories who wanted to start their own company. He helped the scientists, known as the "Traitorous Eight," start Fairchild Semiconductor within Fairchild Camera and Instrument.   Fairchild earned Silicon Valley its status as the heart of the computing industry and gave birth to the Valley tradition of employees' leaving companies, raising capital and founding start-ups, as my colleague Ashlee Vance wrote in his book, "Geek Silicon Valley".   In 1961, Mr. Rock moved to Silicon Valley and created Davis & Rock, an early venture capital firm, with Tommy Davis. They invested in Teledyne and Scientific Data Systems, which Xerox acquired. In 1968, Mr. Rock formed Arthur Rock & Company, another investment firm through which he helped Robert Noyce and Gordon Moore -- two of the "Traitorous Eight" -- form Intel, an investment that made Mr. Rock a billionaire. Later, Mr. Rock invested in Apple when it was still in its infancy.   Mr. Rock's role in creating Silicon Valley earned him a place on the cover of Time magazine in 1984. In 2003, he gave $25 million to Harvard Business School, his alma mater, to form the Arthur Rock Center for Entrepreneurship. Now in his 80s, Mr. Rock still advises and invests in young technology companies through Arthur Rock & Company.   He summed up his investment philosophy for Harvard Business School's Alumni Bulletin in 1997: "If you're interested in building a business to make money, forget it. You won't. If you're interested in building a business to make a contribution to society, then let's talk."
abstract: Arthur Rock, who backed Fairchild Semiconductor, Intel and Apple, invested with Bernard L. Madoff, according to a list made public in bankruptcy court filings Thursday.

headline.main: Arthur Rock, Legendary V.C., Invested With Bernard Madoff
headline.print_headline: Arthur Rock, Legendary V.C., Invested With Bernard Madoff

snippet: Palm, maker of the new Pre smartphone, had its best day in five months in Nasdaq trading after reporting a smaller loss than analysts had estimated and spending less cash.
lead_paragraph: Palm, maker of the new Pre smartphone, had its best day in five months in Nasdaq trading after reporting a smaller loss than analysts had estimated and spending less cash. Palm said it had cash and equivalents of $255.1 million as of May 29, the end of its fourth quarter. The company spent $72.4 million in cash in the period, less than the $92.1 million in the previous quarter. The company plans to start generating cash in the second half of this fiscal year, bolstered by the Pre and its new WebOS operating system. Palm introduced the Pre on June 6, challenging Apple’s iPhone and Research in Motion’s BlackBerry.
abstract: Palm, maker of the new Pre smartphone, had its best day in five months in Nasdaq trading after reporting a smaller loss than analysts had estimated and spending less cash.

snippet: Oprah.com has acknowledged that the author of a memoir who said he had met his wife during the Holocaust had invented portions of his story.
lead_paragraph: Oprah.com, the Web site of Oprah Winfrey, has posted a disclaimer acknowledging that Herman Rosenblat, the author of a memoir that said he had met his wife, Roma, during the Holocaust, had invented portions of his story. “Based on this admission,” the disclaimer said, “the publisher of his forthcoming memoir ‘Angel at the Fence’ canceled plans to print his book.” In “Angel at the Fence,” which was canceled by Berkley Books, Mr. Rosenblat wrote that while he was a prisoner at a concentration camp in Germany he met his future wife at its fence, where she would throw apples to him from the outside; this claim was later disputed by several scholars who said the layout of the camp made this impossible. Ms. Winfrey had featured Mr. Rosenblat on her show, calling his story “the single greatest love story, in 22 years of doing this show, we’ve ever told on the air.” She has not commented publicly on the book’s cancellation.
abstract: Oprah.com has acknowledged that the author of a memoir who said he had met his wife during the Holocaust had invented portions of his story.

headline.main: Winfrey Web Site Notes Fabricated Memoir

Sir John Soane’s Museum in London has a full audio tour (introduced by the actor Stephen Fry) of the collection, available at www.soane.org/audio.html. Apple has audio tours from several museums posted at www.apple.com/ipod/ipodtours.

snippet: A regional restaurant group tries to outfit a Scarsdale location with the trappings of a French bistro.
lead_paragraph: THE Norman-style castle-ette that briefly housed Backals, and before that Heathcote Tavern, is now Bistro Citron. One of a dozen regional restaurants owned by the Reststar Hospitality Group, this new venture, which opened in mid-April, feels like a marketing team’s calculation of a French bistro, right down to the big ceramic rooster that struts in a corner of the main dining room in a static show of bravado. In its effort to deliver traditional bistro fare  crêpes, steak frites, escargots  Bistro Citron has all the circumflexes in place, but the food suffers from a credibility gap as wide as the Champs-Élysées.
abstract: A regional restaurant group tries to outfit a Scarsdale location with the trappings of a French bistro.

snippet: Most Macs aren’t affected by viruses, but that doesn’t mean Mac users can’t make their computers more secure.
lead_paragraph: When news like the rampaging Conficker virus hits, Mac users often feel a certain sense of comfort -- if not smug superiority -- knowing it doesn't affect them.   But just how relaxed (or smug) should Mac users be? It's true that very few viruses have been written for Macs -- and none are spreading actively right now. Similarly, hacker programs distributed by malicious Web sites typically run only on PCs.   Yet Macs' relative safety is primarily due to their still-slim market share. They're simply a waste of time for today's attackers, who are trying to accomplish crime on a large scale by infiltrating millions of computers. And there's nothing inherently more secure about a Mac. Researchers found 26 vulnerabilities in OS X in 2008, about the same as in Windows Vista (27), according to the security software maker Symantec. If its market share rises enough, the Mac will become a target and attacks will succeed.  So, what does this mean for Mac users? Should they buy security software just to be safe? Are there steps to take to minimize risk? I called up Rich Mogull, founder of the security consultancy Securosis and a contributor to the Mac news site TidBITS, to get some answers.   Here's the lowdown:  * For most, security software isn't necessary. "The risk to Mac users at this time is too low, and the benefits provided by extra software are not worth the cost," Mogull says. (Products from Symantec run from $50 a year to $90, while Intego's sell for $40 to $100. See product reviews here.) The exceptions: people whose employers require it and people who are into pornography, online gambling or file sharing. On sketchy sites, you could stumble upon a Trojan horse for Macs, "and they are pretty bad if you get one," he says.  * Use the built-in firewall, especially if you use a laptop in cafes, hotels or other public places. Go to "System Preferences," click "Security" and then "Firewall." Mogull recommends choosing "Set access for specific services and applications," and then allow connections as you need them.   * Use e-mail services that provide virus and spam filtering, like Yahoo Mail, Hotmail, Gmail or Apple's own MobileMe. These providers will quickly block any new viruses.  * For browsing the Web, consider using Firefox with the no-script plug-in. Some users will find it annoyingly disruptive to have every JavaScript blocked, but it's a blessing "for the really paranoid, like me," Mogull says. Also consider using one browser just for banking, a tactic that will protect you from some Web-based attacks.  * Say yes to the software updates Apple sends your way. Many are fixes for security vulnerabilities that could leave you open to attack.   * Keep in mind that many common scams exploit the vulnerabilities of humans, not machines. You are not immune from "phishing" scams that aim to trick you into disclosing sensitive information that can be used in fraud schemes.   So be cool, just not too comfy.
abstract: Most Macs aren’t affected by viruses, but that doesn’t mean Mac users can’t make their computers more secure.

headline.main: Macs Aren't Safer, Just a Smaller Target
headline.print_headline: Macs Aren't Safer, Just a Smaller Target

snippet: New York City is an enduring subject for photographers, and the exhibition “New York Photographs” proves it. The show is the collective effort of numerous photography galleries who’ve all dedicated their spaces this summer to views of the Big Appl...
lead_paragraph: New York City is an enduring subject for photographers, and the exhibition “New York Photographs” proves it. The show is the collective effort of numerous photography galleries who’ve all dedicated their spaces this summer to views of the Big Apple and its inhabitants. There are works by perennial favorites like Alfred Eisenstaedt and Diane Arbus as well as contemporary photographers like Philip-Lorca di Corcia and Andrew Moore. Two of the best shows in the lot are Yancey Richardson’s “Glitz and Grime,” a look at Times Square’s evolution over the years, for better or for worse, and Yossi Milo’s “Sexy and the City,” a prurient peek at lovers, drag queens and exhibitionists. And if you’re just in town for a visit and can’t fit in all the requisite tourist attractions, stop into Hasted Hunt and check out its tribute to America’s most beloved icon, the Statue of Liberty.
abstract: New York City is an enduring subject for photographers, and the exhibition “New York Photographs” proves it. The show is the collective effort of numerous photography galleries who’ve all dedicated their spaces this summer to views of the Big Apple and its inhabitants.

headline.main: In Focus | New York City

snippet: The city's 311 service should appear on your mobile device, City Council members argue.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:52 p.m. | So what would you want from a 311 service on your phone? Real time traffic feeds? An updated list of subway disruptions?  Over the weekend, Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, and Councilwoman Gale A. Brewer suggested the administration create a mobile 311 application for the mobile generation. The specifics are quite mushy, but the idea is that New Yorkers should be able to to check public school closings, find out about alternate-side parking rules suspensions, and to report potholes. (A lot of the calls to 311 are for basic information, according to the city's annual survey, available as a PDF.)   Some 311-type functions -- like uploading a picture of a pothole or looking at traffic cams -- can already be done from a phone through the city's mobile Web site (which is a redirect from www.nyc.gov, courtesy of Usablenet). The problem is that's just not branded under 311. It's splayed all over the nyc.gov site.  As with other cities who have 311 services, like Baltimore and San Francisco, New York's technologists are putting a lot of the information on the Web to streamline the burdens on the operators.  And the city intends to move more of it under the 311 brand. "We are absolutely working toward that," said Nick Sbordone, spokesman for the Department of Information Technology and Telecommunication, the agency that oversees 311. As he explained, 311 "is more a philosophy than a call center," in that it's about presenting information to people when they want it, how they want it.  However, some City Council members said they think there needs to be specific mobile application, not just Web content, since it would also engage the younger generation of New Yorkers. (The agency says it is open to this approach.)  Mobile applications have become the flavor du jour with the latest generation of phones. One of the reasons that Apple lost the desktop war with the PC was that fewer programs were written for the Macintosh. Apple learned its lesson and the company threw open the platform with the iPhone and unleashed developers' creativity. Google's Android phone platform also opened a mobile application store for paid programs. And BlackBerry just announced that it would open an online software retail presence.  The downside? Since no mobile platform -- Palm, Blackberry, Google's Android, iPhone -- has more than a 50 percent market share, the mobile application space is completely fragmented. Developers complain that they have to implement their content hundreds of times.  One thought: Maybe if the city opened its data about schools, parking rules and potholes, it could also attract developers to create 311-type applications. Different groups, including the Sunlight Foundation, have been pushing governments on all levels to release more data in structured form. And Tim Berners-Lee, the creator of the World Wide Web, has a new mantra: Raw. Data. Now.  Maybe we could get ... Raw. City. Data. Now.  Mr. Sbordone was asked if the administration was thinking of opening its application programming interface, or API, as many companies like Google, Flickr, Twitter, and even The New York Times have done.  The city is exploring it, Mr. Sbordone said.  Well. If they are going to create a mobile application, what kind of functionality do you think should be put in it?
abstract: The city's 311 service should appear on your mobile device, City Council members argue.

headline.main: Imagine a 311 Application for the iPhone
headline.print_headline: Imagine a 311 Application for the iPhone

snippet: New York City is an enduring subject for photographers, and the exhibition "New York Photographs" proves it. The show is the collective effort of numerous photography galleries who've all dedicated their spaces this summer to views of the Big Appl...
lead_paragraph: New York City is an enduring subject for photographers, and the exhibition "New York Photographs" proves it. The show is the collective effort of numerous photography galleries who've all dedicated their spaces this summer to views of the Big Apple and its inhabitants. There are works by perennial favorites like Alfred Eisenstaedt and Diane Arbus as well as contemporary photographers like Philip-Lorca di Corcia and Andrew Moore. Two of the best shows in the lot are Yancey Richardson's "Glitz and Grime," a look at Times Square's evolution over the years, for better or for worse, and Yossi Milo's "Sexy and the City," a prurient peek at lovers, drag queens and exhibitionists. And if you're just in town for a visit and can't fit in all the requisite tourist attractions, stop into Hasted Hunt and check out its tribute to America's most beloved icon, the Statue of Liberty.
abstract: New York City is an enduring subject for photographers, and the exhibition "New York Photographs" proves it. The show is the collective effort of numerous photography galleries who've all dedicated their spaces this summer to views of the Big Apple and its inhabitants.

headline.main: ‘New York Photographers’
headline.print_headline: In Focus | New York City

snippet: In the years that the Joint Inaugural Committee of Congress has been serving the traditional lunch to members of Congress, guests and the new first families, security has never been so tight.
lead_paragraph: Update | Fifteen minutes before the guests were scheduled to arrive at the official luncheon at the Capitol, following the swearing-in, one of the tables for 10 had to changed to a table for 12; suddenly another guest was added to the list. Shortly after another two guests had to be squeezed in to another table.  All in a day's work, according to Bill Homan, an owner of Design Cuisine, the catering company.  As the pheasant was being sliced, an adult voice called out: "Watch the plastic, girls," as Malia and Sasha, President Obama's children, appeared in the make-shift kitchen off Statuary Hall in the Capitol. They were on their way to the lunch in the Rayburn room for them and the Biden grandchildren. Sasha was waving her hands like a conductor, keeping time to music on a nearby television.  The lunch began about 20 minutes late, around 1:35 p.m., with a seafood stew and a puff pastry topping, created to take the chill off the bones.  But not before Senator Diane Feinstein, chairwoman of the Joint Inaugural Committee of Congress, announced that more people visited the recipe page than any other page on the Inaugural web site.  Suddenly the makeshift kitchen, which had been very quiet, went into overdrive: voices rose as the supervisors and chefs and waiters became more agitated.  Shh. Shh. Shh.   And eventually everyone quieted down as they rushed to get the food out. After all the meal is supposed to be served and consumed in about an hour. It wasn't.  With 24 tables it is inevitable that some people are being served their main course while others haven't quite finished their soup, which was served with a 2007 Duckhorn sauvignon blanc.  The decibel level rose again as the platters of perfectly cooked duck and pheasant served on a beautiful bed of carrots, asparagus, wax beans, beets and spinach, were readied.  They were followed by pureed sweet potatoes and then miniature corn muffins, into which a small piece of corn husk had been baked.  A 2005 Goldeneye Pinot Noir accompanied the main course.  Dessert service was interrupted when Senator Ted Kennedy, who is undergoing treatment for brain cancer, had a seizure and was rushed to the hospital.  But the show must go on and a cinnamon apple cake with vanilla bean ice cream, sautéed apple cubes and sauce was served with Korbel champagne.  As the lunch ended, President Obama thanked all the appropriate people and then gave a shout-out to the staff for their good work.  The staff was delighted when Senator Hillary Clinton, Mr. Obama's nominee for Secretary of State, told the staff the lunch was "fabulous." She added, "the dessert was excellent."  The day had begun at 4 a.m. in bone-chilling cold, when the van from Design Cuisine commenced its high-security expedition into the capital from Virginia. Their mission was lunch for 234 guests, including the newly sworn in President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., and even with a police escort they were stopped at check points and searched by dogs.  Security dogs were frequent visitors throughout the morning as the caterers and waiter staff went about their business just off Statuary Hall. In the years that the Joint Inaugural Committee of Congress has been serving the traditional lunch to some Congressional leaders, cabinet secretaries and friends of the new first families following the Inauguration ceremony, security has never been so tight.  So tight that Rickie Niceta Lloyd, an account executive for Design Cuisine, slept over in the Capitol building, just to avoid the hassles on Tuesday morning. She was not alone: A group of women slipped into some warm clothes and camped out in the building, to be ready when the food and staff arrived before dawn. "It was just like being in a dorm," she said.  Once in, the cooks and waiter staff quickly got to work, beginning the final steps to prepare the traditional three-course meal. The cooks worked behind a curtain, getting the food, some of which was pre-cooked, ready for serving. The Design Cuisine staff had set the tables earlier. They were covered with blue damask cloths, the chairs covered with matching blue velvet pillows. On each table were centerpieces of white and lavender hydrangeas and two kinds of red roses, a larger display at the head table.  The place plates are copies of the Lincoln china, with the purple border that looked red at the lunch; the silver was gold-plated. Four glasses stood at each plate – two wine, a water glass and a champagne flute.  The menu, like the plates, continued the Abraham Lincoln thread that has run through Mr. Obama's campaign for the presidency, the transition and the Inauguration festivities. It was modeled after a Lincoln menu.  Taking into account Mr. Obama's young children, Malia, 10, and Sasha, 7, and the many Biden grandchildren who were in attendance, there was a children's menu, served in the nearby Rayburn Room.   Hot dogs Cheeseburgers Macaroni and cheese  French fries Grilled cheese sandwiches Cheese pizza Chocolate chip cookies Apple and orange juices and soft drinks    The new president and vice president were presented gifts from Dianne Feinstein, the chairwoman of the Joint Inaugural Committee: heavy glass bowls from Lenox, etched with the White House for Mr. Obama and the Capitol for Mr. Biden.  It was not until 3:30 p.m. that the Obamas left the Capitol, pretty late for a man known for his punctuality.
abstract: In the years that the Joint Inaugural Committee of Congress has been serving the traditional lunch to members of Congress, guests and the new first families, security has never been so tight.

headline.main: High Security for Lunch in the Capitol
headline.print_headline: A Mission to Serve Lunch in the Capitol

snippet: The food at Amarelle is a just-right mix of the earthy and the sophisticated.
lead_paragraph: ON its business card, Amarelle labels its fare “contemporary country cuisine.” That’s an accurate description, but I’ll take it a step further: The food here is a just-right mix of the earthy (melt-in-the-mouth suckling pig served with wilted kale and a moist bacon bread pudding) and the sophisticated (local striped bass atop a purée of creamed butter beans with oven-roasted tomatoes, champagne beurre blanc and basil oil).

snippet: Confirming longstanding rumors, the PC maker Dell has officially announced its entry into the smartphone market.

It will go on sale in Brazil through the wireless carrier Claro (part of the América Móvil network) by year’s end.

snippet: Palm, which is rolling out its new Pre smartphone, might benefit from a partnership with — or even an outright sale to — a deep-pocketed partner, The 451 Group says.
lead_paragraph: It's crunch time for Palm, whose new smartphone, the Pre, is generally getting positive reviews but is also costing a lot of money to roll out.  Palm recently raised some additional cash, and its private equity backer, Elevation Partners, still seems willing to support the company.  Even so, The 451 Group, a technology analysis firm, suggests that Palm might benefit from a partnership with -- or even an outright sale to -- a well-financed company seeking entree into the smartphone business.   Palm could draw interest from computer hardware makers -- possibly Dell or Hewlett-Packard -- or telecom companies such as Alcatel-Lucent, The 451 Group speculates.  An alliance or sale "would give Palm more time to negotiate favorable carrier deals for Pre," the report said, adding that the Pre's exclusive deal with carrier Sprint Nextel might be crimping customer demand.   More importantly, the report says, such a deal could give Palm more support to fund applications -- akin to the iPhone applications sold on Apple's App Store -- to drive interest from both consumers and developers.  Go to Report from The 451 Group>>
abstract: Palm, which is rolling out its new Pre smartphone, might benefit from a partnership with — or even an outright sale to — a deep-pocketed partner, The 451 Group says.

headline.main: Could an Acquirer Reach Out for Palm?
headline.print_headline: Could an Acquirer Reach Out for Palm?

snippet: An orthographic polemic against the use of midword capitals.
lead_paragraph: As you probably know, the California-based company Apple makes a portable communication device — a device that an acquaintance of mine whose first language is not English distinguishes as a “self” phone. Though proper nouns conventionally begin with a capital letter, Apple spells the device’s trademark with an initial lowercase i, followed by an uppercase P. Thus styled, the word has a hump in the middle. I could print it here to show you, but I refuse to allow my prose to be so disfigured.
abstract: An orthographic polemic against the use of midword capitals.

snippet: It is becoming easier to break free of paper and pen and instead rely on computers to take notes that can be archived, cataloged and searched.
lead_paragraph: MODERN life is a mess of notes, a tangle of countless scraps of information that we accumulate during our waking hours. In the morning, you attend a meeting with the boss and jot down everything she says. Later, you get a call from the vet and transcribe results from your dog’s lab tests. At lunch, a friend gives you the name of a Mexican place he says you’ve got to try. And then there are the to-do lists, grocery lists, recipes and all those brilliant ideas for screenplays you get while taking a shower.
abstract: It is becoming easier to break free of paper and pen and instead rely on computers to take notes that can be archived, cataloged and searched.

headline.main: Bringing Order to the Chaos of Notes
