snippet: One of the most bizarre theories in all of science suggests a negative outcome for the superconducting supercollider in Switzerland.
lead_paragraph: More than a year after an explosion of sparks, soot and frigid helium shut it down, the world’s biggest and most expensive physics experiment, known as the Large Hadron Collider, is poised to start up again. In December, if all goes well, protons will start smashing together in an underground racetrack outside Geneva in a search for forces and particles that reigned during the first trillionth of a second of the Big Bang.

snippet: A legendary glutton seems less gluttonous by the moment.
lead_paragraph: (Photo: Diamond Jim Brady (Photo: Brown Brothers)) Earlier this week, David Kamp  fact checked the Diamond Jim Brady legend with admirable thoroughness. Today's mail brings fresh evidence that Brady's accomplishments at table have been somewhat exaggerated over time. Brought to my attention by William Grimes, once the Times's restaurant critic, what follows is a quote about Diamond Jim from Oscar Tschirky, who was the maitre d'hotel of Delmonico's and later of the Waldorf-Astoria.    "Well, I served him myself innumerable times both at Delmonico's and later at the Waldorf, and and if he was a great eater he must have done his stuffing somewhere else. Every time I waited on him his order was always pretty much the same. He loved good food and he wanted it served well. He would start off his supper with a dozen raw oysters. Then he would usually have a small filet mignon with one green vegetable. For dessert there would be either a slice of apple pie or a portion of watermelon, if it were in season. His only beverage was a glass of orange juice."  -- quoted in "Oscar of the Waldorf," by Karl Schriftgiesser
abstract: A legendary glutton seems less gluttonous by the moment.

headline.main: Diamond Jim Goes on a Diet
headline.print_headline: Diamond Jim Goes on a Diet

snippet: This week, Nike introduced an updated SportBand, which works with a sensor to collect your workout data.
lead_paragraph: When I first started writing about tech gear for runners, as part of my own quest to train for a marathon, I was eager to test as many gadgets as possible. In one of my early runs, I set out with a bulky GPS watch that communicated with a heart monitor that was strapped to my chest, a foot sensor that beamed information to an iPod Touch in an armband that occupied the greater part of my upper arm, and headphones. I have to admit, I was a little geeked out.
abstract: This week, Nike introduced an updated SportBand, which works with a sensor to collect your workout data.

headline.main: Marathon Tech Review: Nike SportBand

snippet: A recipe for Tortoni ran in The Times just as the dessert was falling out of fashion.
lead_paragraph: Figuring out the route a recipe took to get from the Alps two centuries ago to your dinner table in Vermont is a bit like tracking a scent in the woods: there are moments of baying enthusiasm followed by dead ends and plenty of sighs. Tortoni, a frozen mousse speckled with crushed macaroons, is no exception. It became the rage in Paris in the early 19th century, wended its way to America, where it found a ravenous following, and then evaporated from our culinary memory.
abstract: A recipe for Tortoni ran in The Times just as the dessert was falling out of fashion.

headline.main: 1898: Tortoni
headline.print_headline: Recipe Redux: 1898: Tortoni

snippet: An orthographic polemic against the use of midword capitals.
lead_paragraph: As you probably know, the California-based company Apple makes a portable communication device — a device that an acquaintance of mine whose first language is not English distinguishes as a “self” phone. Though proper nouns conventionally begin with a capital letter, Apple spells the device’s trademark with an initial lowercase i, followed by an uppercase P. Thus styled, the word has a hump in the middle. I could print it here to show you, but I refuse to allow my prose to be so disfigured.
abstract: An orthographic polemic against the use of midword capitals.

snippet: When Comme des Garçons approached Artek — the 75-year-old Finnish company known for producing Alvar Aalto’s furniture designs — to create a fragrance, one of Artek’s first ideas was to have it smell like one of the company’s showrooms.
lead_paragraph: When Comme des Garçons approached Artek — the 75-year-old Finnish company known for producing Alvar Aalto’s furniture designs — to create a fragrance, one of Artek’s first ideas was to have it smell like one of the company’s showrooms. ‘‘That would have been naïve, to have a scent of birch,’’ says Ville Kokkonen, Artek’s head of design, who explained that ‘‘bottling the scent of chairs’’ just wouldn’t make sense. (Tell that to Herzog & de Meuron, whose 2005 perfume Rotterdam smells like hashish and Rhine water.) Instead, Artek’s result, Standard eau de toilette, evokes the brand through a more subtle blend of linnea borealis flowers, Finnish labrador tea and metal — nature meets machine, as in the classic bentwood chairs for which the company is known. Standard is a major departure for Artek, which is looking to branch out to other cultural platforms; hence the splashy appearance at this summer’s Venice Biennale. But in general, perfumes by designers and architects aren’t quite the rarity they once were: In addition to Herzog & de Meuron, the Japanese architecture firm Sanaa recently released the limited-edition scent Translucence for the New Museum in New York, channeling the lightness of its buildings in notes of musk, freesia and apple.
abstract: When Comme des Garçons approached Artek — the 75-year-old Finnish company known for producing Alvar Aalto’s furniture designs — to create a fragrance, one of Artek’s first ideas was to have it smell like one of the company’s showrooms.

headline.main: Brand Scents | Architects Follow Their Noses

snippet: Slave to a little freedom from the Internet.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after my girlfriend and I decided to rent a New Hampshire summer house together in 2007, we made a vexing discovery: Internet access wasn’t going to be possible. We could get it, sure, but balked at the one-year contract required. We couldn’t justify the expense and decided we would do without: surely our three acres of apple trees and old stone walls and wooded walks would offer ample distraction.
abstract: Slave to a little freedom from the Internet.

snippet: Martha Rose Shulman offers five ways to cook with walnuts, a surprisingly underrated health food.
lead_paragraph: The walnut is a surprisingly underrated health food. Studies show regular walnut consumption is associated with lowering bad cholesterol, raising good cholesterol and lowering risk for heart disease. In animal studies, walnuts have even been associated with slowing breast cancer growth.

snippet: Perhaps you’ve laughed-or heckled-at my many mishaps planting vegetables for the first time. So how does your garden grow?
lead_paragraph: The tomatoes are blighted and losing their leaves. The blue Jarrahdale pumpkins are almost done flowering. And the pickling cucumbers are spreading as if they have a mind to creep in the nursery window and make off with the baby. The story of my starter garden seems to have as many plotlines as "Lost"-and as many dark portents. One week, the American rapa makes a tasty dinner salad; the next, it's tougher than a comedy club audience on open-mic night.

snippet: This week, the Android market will throw the door open to developers who want to charge for applications.
lead_paragraph: The Android market, where people go to get applications for their T-Mobile G1 Google Phones, had allowed only free apps on the site, but this week will throw the door open to developers who want to charge for applications. Payments will be made through Google Checkout, natch.  (Photo:  ) That could be good news for Android app shoppers. Developers who were holding back products they think are too good to give away will finally break out their wares.  A Google spokesperson said the company had no idea how many apps were waiting, or what they would be, although based on mobile business history, the answer is probably a lot of games.  I'm hoping it's good news for another reason. Maybe charging for apps will inspire the Android Market to become easier to shop.   With more than 1,000 apps in the market, you pretty much have to look at them one-by-one on the phone, or browse the few displayed on the Web site. I would think with Google's excellent search technology, the market would be organized better than Apple's iTunes App market, which I also find lacking.  How about more ways to sort results? By price, popularity, rating or a combination? Maybe an option to read the reviews by star groupings, like Amazon does? Or a better way to discover unknown but worthwhile apps?  C'mon Google, this is your wheelhouse.
abstract: This week, the Android market will throw the door open to developers who want to charge for applications.

headline.main: Will Paid Apps Make Android Organize?
headline.print_headline: Will Paid Apps Make Android Organize?

snippet: In this novel set in Peru, a married man falls in love with a teenage dancer.
lead_paragraph: “I am always surprised to learn that people do not live with memories of fragrance as I do,” Marie Arana wrote in “American Chica,” her gloriously redolent memoir of growing up as the daughter of a Peruvian father and an American mother. If books came with ­perfumed-page inserts, Arana’s new novel, “Lima Nights,” would smell of bougainvillea and lemons, with an acrid hint of Molotov cocktails and a potent under­pinning of sausages and apples. These last two infuse the combustible rapport of its two Peruvian lovers, Carlos Bluhm and Juana Maria Fernandez.

snippet: A panel at the New Yorker magazine festival discussed “Mad Men” for 90 minutes without once bringing up Don’s love life, Betty’s abortive affair, Sal’s dilemma or Pete’s caddishness.
lead_paragraph: Years ago, people joked that an intellectual is someone who can listen to “The William Tell Overture” without once thinking about the Lone Ranger. The modern-daly equivalent took place on Saturday morning during a session of the annual New Yorker magazine festival as a panel discussed “Mad Men” for 90 minutes without once bringing up Don’s love life, Betty’s abortive affair, Sal’s dilemma, Pete’s caddishness or what the heck Conrad Hilton meant when he said in last Sunday’s episode that he wanted the moon.
abstract: A panel at the New Yorker magazine festival discussed “Mad Men” for 90 minutes without once bringing up Don’s love life, Betty’s abortive affair, Sal’s dilemma or Pete’s caddishness.

snippet: On Friday, British Prime Minister Gordon Brown issued a public apology to Alan Turing, a mathematician and computer pioneer whose work as a code-breaker during World War II helped defeat Nazi Germany.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain issued a public apology to Alan Turing, a mathematician and computer pioneer whose work as a code breaker during World War II helped defeat Nazi Germany. Mr. Turing was convicted of "gross indecency" in 1952 for having a homosexual affair and was forced to endure injections of female hormones. Two years later, killed himself by biting into a poisoned apple.
abstract: On Friday, British Prime Minister Gordon Brown issued a public apology to Alan Turing, a mathematician and computer pioneer whose work as a code-breaker during World War II helped defeat Nazi Germany.

headline.main: Apology to a Gay Code Breaker
headline.print_headline: Posthumous Apology to Gay Code Breaker Who Helped Defeat Nazi Germany

snippet: An advance look at the Playstation PSP Go — the coming portable gaming platform from Sony.
lead_paragraph: If you want to quickly understand Sony’s PSP Go ($250, coming Oct. 1), just think of the rule of two. Compared with the regular PSP, it is 50 percent smaller, but it costs costs twice as much as Nintendo’s DS, which is outselling it by 100 percent. The new form factor is twice as cool as the older, more clunky PSP 3000, meaning you’re also twice as likely to make room for one next to your phone.

lead_paragraph: LONDON  At first glance Johnny (Rooster) Byron  the central figure in “Jerusalem,” the great sprawling brawl of a play by Jez Butterworth at the Royal Court Theater here  seems an utterly contemporary figure. Inhabited with frightening fierceness by Mark Rylance, the unemployed, tax-evading, perpetually stoned Johnny might be a cousin of the Gallaghers, the squalid family of losers in the popular British television series “Shameless.”

snippet: Denial, anger and other stages of grieving a hard drive’s death.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, my laptop suffered a fall onto linoleum that made its congenitally nervous hard drive more nervous even than usual. Fortunately, days later, the drive turned miraculously tranquil, efficient. Its anxieties disappeared, as if by magic. There was no freezing or whirring. I wrote some e-mail messages, surfed the Web and organized some photos before shutting things down.

snippet: There's been some interesting recent commentary on the Human Development Index. But first, some background. This index is calculated each year by the U.N. Development Program as a summary indicator ...
lead_paragraph: There's been some interesting recent commentary on the Human Development Index. But first, some background. This index is calculated each year by the U.N. Development Program as a summary indicator of "Human Development," combining data on life expectancy at birth, adult literacy, educational enrollment, and average income (measured as G.D.P. per capita). And earlier this week, Catherine Rampell noted a recent effort by the SSRC-funded American Human Development Project to develop a Human Development Index, for U.S. states. Philosophically, it is an attempt to broaden the development debate beyond G.D.P. But does it succeed?
abstract: There's been some interesting recent commentary on the Human Development Index. But first, some background. This index is calculated each year by the U.N. Development Program as a summary indicator of "Human Development," combining data on life expectancy at birth, adult literacy, educational enrollment, and average income (measured as G.D.P. per capita). And earlier this week, Catherine Rampell noted a recent effort by the SSRC-funded American Human Development Project to develop a Human Development Index, for U.S. states. Philosophically, it is an attempt to broaden the development debate beyond G.D.P. But does it succeed?.

snippet: NYC Seed, a new early-stage investment fund that finances New York City start-ups, made initial $200,000 investments in Path101 and PlaceVine.
lead_paragraph: New York City has always been a destination for actors, singers, models and musicians hoping to someday see their names in lights. Now, NYC Seed, an early-stage technology fund, wants to help transform the Big Apple into a thriving incubator for Internet start-ups.    "New York is highly underleveraged," said Owen Davis, managing director of NYC Seed. "Start-up companies are a great way to do that."   Mr. Davis hopes that by financing newborn local start-ups, the company can expand New York's technical infrastructure and infuse it with some of the ebullient start-up spirit that resonates throughout Silicon Valley.   "The idea that there's not enough capital at this level of funding is one of the things we were trying to address," he said.   To that end, he's brought together some of the crucial components that nurture the West Coast's start-up community. For starters, he enlisted local government agencies and universities to contribute to the fund, which is a partnership of the New York City Investment Fund, Polytechnic Institute of N.Y.U. and the New York City Economic Development Corporation, among others. The organizers have amassed a bankroll of $2 million and will invest up to $200,000 per homegrown start-up.   In addition, the company recruited notable venture capitalists and entrepreneurs for the company's advisory board, including Drew Lipsher of Greycroft Venture Partners and Fred Wilson of Union Square Ventures, to help guide the budding companies through development.   So far, the community has been responding: Mr. Davis estimated that since NYC Seed was unveiled in June, the company has received upwards of 300 pitches. On Monday, the company announced the first two start-ups selected to receive $200,000 each:   Path101 functions as a recommendation engine, like the ones used by iTunes, Amazon and Pandora, but for careers. The Web-based service analyzes résumés and uses personality quizzes to help job seekers find relevant openings in their disciplines.   PlaceVine plays online matchmaker for product placements in film, television and Web shows. The company works with content producers like Fox Films and FunnyorDie to list coming opportunities for marketers to insert branded cans of soda, laptops and labels into their projects.   Mr. Davis said the company hoped to dole out financing to another four start-ups in the next few months. He also said NYC Seed is open to all types of start-up ideas, but prototypes involving social media middleware, real-time search tools, online advertising networks and location-based services have been the most successful at snagging his attention. The only real criterion for applying, he said, is that founders be based in one of the five boroughs.
abstract: NYC Seed, a new early-stage investment fund that finances New York City start-ups, made initial $200,000 investments in Path101 and PlaceVine.

headline.main: Nurturing New York Start-Ups
headline.print_headline: NYC Seed Nurtures Homegrown Start-Ups

snippet: Bloomberg puts some of its financial markets data onto the iPhone.
lead_paragraph: (Photo: )   If you have any money left to invest, a program from Bloomberg offers a wealth of basic stock market data and news on the iPhone for free.  The program, just called "Bloomberg," opens a ticker for the world's stock markets, but can also show markets for bonds, commodities or currencies. Go a little deeper in stocks, you'll find a chart showing how different industries are faring, or which companies stocks are highest in gains or losses.  (Photo: ) You can track your own portfolio in the My Stocks section. Apple's stock results come already loaded, but with a negative 36 percent return over 52 weeks, the company might want to rethink that.  The Stock Finder section gives a description of a company and related news, as well as daily highs and lows, with a 52-week performance summary and chart.   The tiny chart is hard to read, but turn the phone sideways and it automatically goes to a full-screen view. Stocks you have looked up are saved in the stock finder menu, so you can check them again without having to do a new search.  There is a link to download Bloomberg Podcasts (if you need a good sweat, try "Paul Krugman Sees Need to Get Stimulus Plan Out `Fast'").  And if there should happen to be a cheerful story in the news section, a button sends it directly to friends who can then be coaxed back off the ledge.  For compulsive market-watchers, Bloomberg offers the global market collapse in a tidy, easy-to-use package. Cheers!

snippet: A tempting straightaway in Central Park is supposed to be off limits to pedicabs.

But the long arm of the law still drew plenty of stares from passers-by on a recent Sunday along the Central Park Mall, the long promenade leading to the Bethesda Terrace. At one moment, three pedicab drivers, some with passengers still ensconced, were pulled over almost simultaneously by enforcement officers and issued summonses.“Pedicabs are not allowed to be on pedestrian pathways, and obviously the Mall is a major pedestrian pathway,” said Douglas Blonsky, the Central Park administrator and president of the Central Park Conservancy, the private, nonprofit organization that manages the park under contract with the Department of Parks and Recreation.

That was the last they heard of me for four days.

snippet: How to change the time-and-date stamp on your pictures.
lead_paragraph: The time and date settings on my digital camera were wrong but I didn't realize it until after I got back from vacation. Is there a way to change the dates on the pictures on the computer?  Depending on what system you use, you have at least a couple of options for correcting the date and time information on your photo files.  The Windows Photo Gallery program that comes with Windows Vista can change picture dates and times. Open it from the Programs in the Start menu and click Info in the toolbar to open the Info pane. Click on the picture or pictures you want to adjust and then click on the date in the Info pane. Click on the arrow next to the date and then choose the correct date on the calendar.  The photo's time can be adjusted in a similar way in the Info pane's time area. Microsoft has more information here.  Shareware programs that let you edit the photo's embedded data can also do the job. Exifer is one such program for Windows XP and there are plenty of other similar applications in shareware archives around the Web like Download.com.  Mac OS X users can change picture dates and times in recent versions of the free iPhoto program that comes with new Apple computers. To use iPhoto, open the program and select the photos that need to be adjusted. Go to the Photos menu and choose Adjust Date and Time to fix the picture timestamps.  The Mac is no stranger to shareware either. Freeware programs like Photo Time Edit are another option.  You can also fiddle with photo timestamps in commercial programs like Adobe Photoshop Elements. Sample instructions are here.
abstract: How to change the time-and-date stamp on your pictures.

headline.main: Time Travel for Photos
headline.print_headline: Time Travel for Photos

lead_paragraph: Who: Francesco Clark of Clark's Botanicals. The handsome young Clark was paralyzed from the waist down after a pool-diving accident in 2002. He not only lost his ability to walk, he also ceased being able to sweat, which led to clogged pores and chronic breakouts. Together with his father, a doctor trained in both Western medicine and homeopathy, he developed a line of organic botanical products to help rebalance and soothe his skin.

snippet: The Wayne County Star in western New York has found that offensive remarks on its Web site came from Internet protocol addresses at the agency.

Still others made personal attacks about the reporter who wrote the article.

snippet: The Palm Pre phone has a big idea: make contact files from different sources appear as one.
lead_paragraph: (Photo: Palm Pre) I haven't gotten to handle the new Palm Pre phone, so I called someone who has, Avi Greengart, research director for Mobile Devices at Current Analysis. His take: "If you live on mobile sites and your goal is to manage all of your personal information and to manage it on the go, the Palm Pre may be the best."  The reason is the phone's outstanding feature: it can collect all of your contact information from disparate places -- say, Outlook files from your computer, corporate files from the office, Web directories like Facebook -- and make them appear as a single contact list on the phone.   It will perform a similar feat for e-mail and instant messaging.  The features are described in a slow-moving keynote speech that you can see in an HD movie online.   As exciting as Mr. Greengart found the Pre, he was quick to point out that the new Palm operating system, WebOS, is "a terrific interface, but there is a learning curve." For that reason it won't crush the easy-to-use iPhone. But, said Mr. Greengart, "It doesn't have to be a iPhone killer, it has to be an iPhone competitor."  The Pre will be offered by Sprint in the first half of 2009. No price has been announced.  Releasing a single phone with a single carrier is a risky move for Palm, which essentially created the personal digital assistant market, but has lost ground to R.I.M., Apple and Windows phones. "I don't want to be too rosy here. This is really a bet-the-company move," said Mr. Greengart. The Pre has to attract app developers who are more focused on the larger and growing audience already using iPhones and BlackBerry phones. Not to mention those phone owners themselves.
abstract: The Palm Pre phone has a big idea: make contact files from different sources appear as one.

headline.main: Palm Pre: For Mobile People Who Live Online
headline.print_headline: Palm Pre: For Mobile People Who Live Online

snippet: Design has changed dramatically over the past 70 years, as Tim Brown relates in his new book.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The bet was for $50,000. It was offered by George Washington Hill, president of the American Tobacco Company, to the designer Raymond Loewy, in 1940. The challenge was to spruce up the packaging of Lucky Strike cigarettes. Loewy accepted the wager, and Hill asked when he expected to finish. “Oh, I don’t know,” drawled the designer. “Some nice spring morning I will feel like designing the Lucky package... I’ll call you then.”
abstract: Design has changed dramatically over the past 70 years, as Tim Brown relates in his new book.

lead_paragraph: Patrick Stewart has won a third Laurence Olivier award for his role of Claudius in "Hamlet." Stewart landed best supporting actor for the Royal Shakespeare Company production, which starred David Tennant in the title role. Derek Jacobi won best actor for playing Malvolio in "Twelfth Night," with Douglas Hodge winning for his cross-dressing role in "La Cage Aux Folles." The musical was also named best revival. "Jersey Boys" scooped the best new musical title, and Elena Roger won best actress in a musical for playing the French singer Edith Piaf. Margaret Tyzack was the winner of best actress in a play for portraying the wife of the writer Somerset Maugham in "The Chalk Garden." A special Olivier award was presented to the playwright Alan Ayckbourn by Kevin Spacey, director of the Old Vic. (BBC)

snippet: Acer aggressively chases the PC market with new notebooks.
lead_paragraph: (Photo:  Acer Timeline series laptop.)   As fast as the computer industry moves, Acer seems to move faster.  Spearheading the netbook movement and regularly undercutting the higher-priced spreads of laptops offered by the competition, Acer is surging ahead in market share, and while it's still chasing Hewlett-Packard and Dell, the company, which is based in Taiwan, is not letting up.  Just this week, the company unwrapped its Timeline series of notebooks, with prices starting at about $700. That's $700 for Acer's flagship product. Power-saving is the angle with the Timelines, as Acer claims up to 8 hours of battery life with a conventional hard drive, and 10 hours with a solid-state drive. The heaviest model in the lineup is just more than five pounds; the lightest is 3.5 pounds. Compare the Timeline to Dell's new Adamo, selling at more than twice the price.  And as for the cool factor, well, it's evident. The Aspire Timelines promise to turn the heat down with their "Laminar Wall Jet" technology, which is supposed to redirect cooling air along the bottom side of the notebook. Developed with Intel, Laminar Wall Jet incorporates a design used to cool turbine blades. Cool!  There are a few screen sizes, from 13 inches to 15 inches, an Apple-like trackpad that supports pinch functions, and scads of options and add-ons. "We are confident we have exceeded our customers' expectations once again," said Acer's chief executive, Gianfranco Lanci.  Mr. Lanci said in an interview with Business Week that his company's low overhead and outsourcing strategies gave Acer an edge in aggressively cutting prices. The company is also jumping into the smartphone market. "To run a business with lower costs is good when the market is growing," Mr. Lanci said. "It's even better when the market is not growing."
abstract: Acer aggressively chases the PC market with new notebooks.

headline.main: Essentially Cool: Acer's Timeline Notebooks

snippet: Researchers at Symantec have found what may be the first successful Mac “botnet.”
lead_paragraph: Malicious programs for Macs are rare and, even when they do show up, rather primitive. Well, they just became a little less rare and a bit more sophisticated.   A pair of researchers at the security software maker Symantec have found what may be the first successful Mac "botnet," ZDNET reports.   A botnet is a group of computers -- often home machines -- that have been quietly infiltrated, commandeered and networked by attackers so they can be used to carry out any number of nefarious acts. This one has apparently been making denial-of-service attacks against an unnamed Web site, which means it has been hitting the site with tons of Web traffic in an effort to knock it out of service.   According to the Symantec researchers, the botnet has some sophisticated capabilities that suggest the work of an experienced programmer who may have rented out his creation to someone else who actually used it for denial-of-service attacks, a common pattern seen in botnets formed from Windows PCs.   Attackers created the botnet by seeding BitTorrent and other file-sharing sites with pirated software that contained a Trojan Horse. Some 20,000 Mac users had downloaded bad copies of Apple's iWork 09 by the time Intego, a security software company that sells products for Macs, publicized its findings in January. Intego found a second version of the Trojan Horse a few days later inside copies of Adobe Photoshop CS4 for Mac.   This activity is still somewhat primitive, says Dino A. Dai Zovi, an independent security researcher and author of "The Mac Hackers Handbook." "Trojaned pirated software is still an early phase in the rise of malware on a platform. But that means that more hostile attacks can't be too far behind."
abstract: Researchers at Symantec have found what may be the first successful Mac “botnet.”

headline.main: Mac Security III: The Rise of the Botnets
headline.print_headline: Mac Security III: The Rise of the Botnets

headline.main: Mac Security III: The Rise of the Botnets

snippet: Researchers at Symantec have found what may be the first successful Mac “botnet.”
lead_paragraph: Malicious programs for Macs are rare and, even when they do show up, rather primitive. Well, they just became a little less rare and a bit more sophisticated.   A pair of researchers at the security software maker Symantec have found what may be the first successful Mac "botnet," ZDNET reports.   A botnet is a group of computers -- often home machines -- that have been quietly infiltrated, commandeered and networked by attackers so they can be used to carry out any number of nefarious acts. This one has apparently been making denial-of-service attacks against an unnamed Web site, which means it has been hitting the site with tons of Web traffic in an effort to knock it out of service.   According to the Symantec researchers, the botnet has some sophisticated capabilities that suggest the work of an experienced programmer who may have rented out his creation to someone else who actually used it for denial-of-service attacks, a common pattern seen in botnets formed from Windows PCs.   Attackers created the botnet by seeding BitTorrent and other file-sharing sites with pirated software that contained a Trojan Horse. Some 20,000 Mac users had downloaded bad copies of Apple's iWork 09 by the time Intego, a security software company that sells products for Macs, publicized its findings in January. Intego found a second version of the Trojan Horse a few days later inside copies of Adobe Photoshop CS4 for Mac.   This activity is still somewhat primitive, says Dino A. Dai Zovi, an independent security researcher and author of "The Mac Hackers Handbook." "Trojaned pirated software is still an early phase in the rise of malware on a platform. But that means that more hostile attacks can't be too far behind."
abstract: Researchers at Symantec have found what may be the first successful Mac “botnet.”

headline.main: Mac Security III: The Rise of the Botnets
headline.print_headline: Mac Security III: The Rise of the Botnets

snippet: Acer aggressively chases the PC market with new notebooks.
lead_paragraph: (Photo:  Acer Timeline series laptop.)   As fast as the computer industry moves, Acer seems to move faster.  Spearheading the netbook movement and regularly undercutting the higher-priced spreads of laptops offered by the competition, Acer is surging ahead in market share, and while it's still chasing Hewlett-Packard and Dell, the company, which is based in Taiwan, is not letting up.  Just this week, the company unwrapped its Timeline series of notebooks, with prices starting at about $700. That's $700 for Acer's flagship product. Power-saving is the angle with the Timelines, as Acer claims up to 8 hours of battery life with a conventional hard drive, and 10 hours with a solid-state drive. The heaviest model in the lineup is just more than five pounds; the lightest is 3.5 pounds. Compare the Timeline to Dell's new Adamo, selling at more than twice the price.  And as for the cool factor, well, it's evident. The Aspire Timelines promise to turn the heat down with their "Laminar Wall Jet" technology, which is supposed to redirect cooling air along the bottom side of the notebook. Developed with Intel, Laminar Wall Jet incorporates a design used to cool turbine blades. Cool!  There are a few screen sizes, from 13 inches to 15 inches, an Apple-like trackpad that supports pinch functions, and scads of options and add-ons. "We are confident we have exceeded our customers' expectations once again," said Acer's chief executive, Gianfranco Lanci.  Mr. Lanci said in an interview with Business Week that his company's low overhead and outsourcing strategies gave Acer an edge in aggressively cutting prices. The company is also jumping into the smartphone market. "To run a business with lower costs is good when the market is growing," Mr. Lanci said. "It's even better when the market is not growing."
abstract: Acer aggressively chases the PC market with new notebooks.

headline.main: Essentially Cool: Acer's Timeline Notebooks
headline.print_headline: Essentially Cool: Acer's Timeline Notebooks

snippet: Making heads and tails of competing video-on-demand products.

abstract: Making heads and tails of competing video-on-demand products.

headline.main: Vudu, Roku, Boxee: What’s the Difference?

snippet: Making heads and tails of competing video-on-demand products.
lead_paragraph: As with your friends' children, odds are you've heard about home-media players from Vudu, Roku and Boxee but are still not able to tell them apart. Here's a quick guide to help you get better acquainted.  Vudu (The Oldest Child)  What It Is: A box that lets you rent or buy movies to watch instantly on your television.  Price: $150.  Rental Fees: Renting standard-definition movies costs $1 to $4; high-definition and HDX movies (see below for explanation) cost $4 to $6. Users can also buy TV episodes for $2 and movies from $5 to $20.  Number of Titles: 14,000 movies and TV episodes, including what the company calls "the largest HD library anywhere" with over 1,400 movies.   The Good: Great picture quality, clean user interface and no monthly fee. Vudu delivers actual HD-quality viewing (up to 1080p) and 5.1 Dolby surround sound thanks in part to deals with Lionsgate, Paramount and Universal Studios. Vudu also offers 500 titles in HDX, a video format that has been optimized for 40-inch and larger HDTVs. But be warned: HDX download times are long -- think hours, not minutes. Users can buy movies the same day they're released on DVD.  The Bad: Erases rented movies after 24 hours, after which you have to pay $1 for a one-day extension. No built-in Wi-Fi, but a Vudu Wireless kit costs $80.  What's New: Vudu just added the Web-based music application Pandora to its collection of more than 120 Web-based video content channels, which already includes Picasa, YouTube and Flickr.  Roku (The Middle Child)  What It Is: The Roku digital video player, also known as the Netflix Player by Roku, is a box that streams Netflix and Amazon Video On Demand movies over the Internet to your television.  Price: $100.  Rental Fees: Roku requires a Netflix unlimited instant-watch account, which starts at $9. Amazon has both rental and purchase options. Rentals cost about $1 to $4. Purchases run from about $1 for TV shows and about $15 for movies.  Number of Titles: Over 50,000. (About 12,000 from Netflix and 40,000 from Amazon).  The Good: A lot of companies claim their units can be installed by a child. The Roku actually can. I was up and running in three minutes. The "getting started" manual is one of the simplest, most dummy-proof visual guides I've seen. The Roku also comes with built-in Wi-Fi so no adapter is needed and it's extremely compact (5.1 inches by 5.1 inches by 1.6 inches) so it won't hog your living space.  The Bad: The No. 1 gripe is its limited selection. Netflix's Instant Watch option trails Netflix's much larger DVD-by-mail catalog. My Netflix Instant Watch lists 1995's "To Die For" and 1998's "The Waterboy" among its "new" movie releases. By comparison, my new movie releases for the DVD-by-mail option include "Changeling" and "Burn After Reading." I also encountered some buffering delays when I used the fast-forward/rewind controls.  What's New: This summer, Roku will release its software developer's kit for Web video providers, so expect more channels. It will also soon offer ad-supported and free content. The company is looking into online photo and music services.  Boxee (The Youngest Child)  What It Is: This service integrates and creates a single interface for the photos, music and video on your computer's hard drive. Boxee also lets users stream content from Netflix, YouTube, CNN.com and other sites for access on your television.  Price: Free.  The Good: No box needed. Downloads straight onto your desktop. Also good if you enjoy the social-networking aspect of entertainment. Boxee automatically updates your Twitter, Tumblr and FriendFeed accounts and shares your friends' activity so you can follow, recommend and find new content. The service also works on Apple TV and, because it operates on an open-source platform, allows users to personalize what they view by letting them add music and video sites.  The Bad: Have to sit through commercials. For now, Boxee is only compatible with Mac and Linux computers. Another snag: Earlier this month, the free online video service Hulu blocked the Boxee browser from accessing its site. Best case situation? The Hulu block proves to be an isolated incident. Worst case? Other companies follow suit. Also, Boxee works only on content without digital rights management. And the nontechie Boxee user will probably find configuring Linux and Apple TV difficult.  What's New: New alpha version released March 24.
abstract: Making heads and tails of competing video-on-demand products.

headline.main: Vudu, Roku, Boxee: What's the Difference?
headline.print_headline: Vudu, Roku, Boxee: What's the Difference?

lead_paragraph: The cherry-red interior of the Cappellini flagship store in SoHo has always reminded me of candy — it’s the color of Red Vines, Swedish Fish, Atomic Fireballs, Hot Tamales, Abracabubbles, Cinnamon Discs, Red Hots and candy apples. So it seems fitting that from now until Jan. 3, the Italian furnishings shop will also be in the sweets business. “The Candy Shoppe: Papabubble x Cappellini” is this year’s holiday installation by the curators Tobias Wong and Josee Lepage, who asked the artisanal candy makers Papabubble to create what they call a “shoppe-in-shop” just inside Cappellini’s front doors. At an opening party last weekend, filled with fashionably dressed tots and their design-loving parents, limited-edition confections were stored in jars and honey pots on Cappellini’s Passepartout shelves and piled high in the polished acrylic drawers of a staircase-like cabinet by Shrio Kuramata.

snippet: At least a dozen were also injured when a van plowed into a crowd.
lead_paragraph: (Photo: Police investigated on Thursday after a delivery van hit a crowd of people, including a group of preschoolers, on a busy commercial street in Chinatown. (Photo: John Marshall Mantel for The New York Times))   Updated, 11:21 p.m. | An unoccupied delivery van that had been left in reverse backed into a crowd of people, including a group of preschoolers, on a busy commercial street in Chinatown on Thursday morning, killing two small children and injuring a dozen other people, the authorities said. (Please read the updated article from Friday's print edition.)  The accident occurred at 11:31 a.m. outside the Wing Hing Center, a commercial building at 39 East Broadway, between Market and Catherine Streets.   The authorities said that a 4-year-old girl, Hayley Ng of the Lower East Side, was killed almost immediately. She was pronounced dead at the scene.   Two other children, a 3-year-old boy and a 4-year-old girl, were critically injured and taken to New York Downtown Hospital. There, about an hour later, the boy, identified as Diego Martinez, of Chelsea, died.   "Despite heroic efforts of our emergency-room staff, the child was pronounced dead," at 12:33 p.m., said Dr. Warren B. Licht, the hospital's chief medical officer. "Everything possible was tried to save this child's life."   Eleven other people, both children and adults, sustained minor injuries. Some were taken to New York Downtown Hospital, and others to Bellevue Hospital Center.   When the accident occurred, around 14 children were being led in a "daisy chain" line -- holding onto each other and accompanied by adult chaperons -- along East Broadway from a library visit back to their day care program, the Red Apple Child Development Center, at 25 Market Street, the police said.   The van, a 2000 Ford, was traveling on East Broadway and appeared to make a three-point turn to make a delivery. Shortly after -- witnesses at times gave conflicting accounts -- the van lurched, going in reverse over the curb and onto the sidewalk, according to witnesses.  Early in the day, the police had said that before the accident the van had stopped and the driver had gotten out, and that the vehicle then began to move, without anyone behind the wheel. The police later appeared to retract that account, but by Thursday evening the authorities were again saying that the driver, Chao Fu, 52, had double-parked and entered a store, leaving the van running and in reverse gear, thinking it was in park. Mr. Fu was not charged.   Alma Torres, 49, who was standing across the street from the scene of the accident, said of the driver: "He backed up. He jumped the curb. You heard the bang. People started running." Ms. Torres said she later saw a Chinese woman, distraught and screaming.   Anthony Amoroso, 50, who lives in East New York, Brooklyn, said of the driver: "He was making a three-point turn. He backed up onto the sidewalk." All he heard after that, Mr. Amoroso, was "the screaming."  Another man, Kenneth Martin, 41, of Bushwick, Brooklyn, saw the aftermath of the accident and described seeing a girl being placed in an ambulance. "She was scared," Mr. Martin said. "Her arms were lifted up."   Pamela Leitstein, 48, who is also from East New York, said: "It was chaos." Katharine Montaldo, 39, from the East Village, said: "I heard screaming. I came running up. All I saw was blood."   Police officials said the driver of the truck did not leave the scene of the accident. Witnesses gave varying accounts of the driver's actions after the crash: one said he left the van as if in a state of shock, while another witness that police officers removed the driver from the van.   A silver-gray van with the name of a company, China Chalet, emblazoned on its side was sitting on the sidewalk along the east side of East Broadway on Thursday afternoon.   On the sidewalk, directly behind the van and in front of the building, the police placed cloth sheets across the sidewalk. The sheets were stained with blood; at moments, the wind briefly blew off one of the sheet, revealing the crumpled body of a small child, wearing gray pants.   A woman who answered the phone Thursday afternoon at China Chalet's office, at 47 Broadway, declined to confirm that its truck was involved in the accident, but said in Chinese that "something happened." The woman said the company's owner was not available for comment, and then hung up.   The block of East Broadway where the accident occurred is a crowded commercial corridor, filled with restaurants and food shops at the base of tenement buildings.  At 33 East Broadway, a few doors down from the scene of the accident, is the historic Chatham Square Branch of the New York Public Library. The branch opened in 1903 and was designed by the architectural firm of McKim, Mead and White.   The Red Apple Child Development Center, where the children were enrolled, has two licenses, one for infants and toddlers and one for children 2 to 6 years, according to the Bureau of Child Care at the city's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene.   A woman who answered the phone at the child care center on Thursday afternoon said that the situation was unclear. She said in Chinese, "We don't have any information right now."  At about 2 p.m., a grief-stricken man and woman clutching each other were quickly escorted out of the child-care center by police and into a waiting police van, which sped down the street, sirens blaring. The man and woman did not answer questions from reporters.   Later on Thursday afternoon, Xiaoping Fan, director of the day-care center, said in a statement released by its lawyer, Robert S. Wolf:     All of us at Red Apple Child Development Center are stunned and deeply saddened by this tragic accident. Our hearts go out to the families of all of the children involved and especially to the two families who suffered the loss of their child. We are doing everything possible to provide support to our students, parents, and their loved ones.    The Manhattan borough president, Scott M. Stringer, who went to the scene of the accident, said in a statement afterward that the accident pointed up the need to better protect pedestrians. Mr. Stringer said:   The Zip code in which 38 East Broadway is located had 25 fatalities and 1,149 injuries from 1995 to 2005, more fatalities than any other Manhattan zip code. And the intersection of Essex and Delancey Streets, located just a few blocks from where today's accident occurred, is the third most dangerous location for Manhattan pedestrians. While the city has taken some important steps to manage traffic in Chinatown, including bollards, better lane designations, and other "traffic calming" measures, it is clear that more needs to be done, particularly given the congestion created by the continued closing of Park Row, which has been shut to most traffic since 9/11.  In New York City overall last year some 300 people were killed in traffic accidents -- nearly one person every day -- and hundreds more were injured, with children and the elderly being particularly vulnerable on our congested streets. The city must take a systematic look in every neighborhood at measures like sidewalk bollards and speed bumps, as well as strict traffic enforcement, to make it safer for New Yorkers to walk the streets of their city.  Sewell Chan, David Giambusso, Kirk Semple and Jennifer 8. Lee contributed reporting.
abstract: At least a dozen were also injured when a van plowed into a crowd.

headline.main: 2 Children Killed in Chinatown Crash
headline.print_headline: 2 Children Killed by Van in Chinatown

snippet: Making heads and tails of competing video-on-demand products.
lead_paragraph: As with your friends' children, odds are you've heard about home-media players from Vudu, Roku and Boxee but are still not able to tell them apart. Here's a quick guide to help you get better acquainted.  Vudu (The Oldest Child)  What It Is: A box that lets you rent or buy movies to watch instantly on your television.  Price: $150.  Rental Fees: Renting standard-definition movies costs $1 to $4; high-definition and HDX movies (see below for explanation) cost $4 to $6. Users can also buy TV episodes for $2 and movies from $5 to $20.  Number of Titles: 14,000 movies and TV episodes, including what the company calls "the largest HD library anywhere" with over 1,400 movies.   The Good: Great picture quality, clean user interface and no monthly fee. Vudu delivers actual HD-quality viewing (up to 1080p) and 5.1 Dolby surround sound thanks in part to deals with Lionsgate, Paramount and Universal Studios. Vudu also offers 500 titles in HDX, a video format that has been optimized for 40-inch and larger HDTVs. But be warned: HDX download times are long -- think hours, not minutes. Users can buy movies the same day they're released on DVD.  The Bad: Erases rented movies after 24 hours, after which you have to pay $1 for a one-day extension. No built-in Wi-Fi, but a Vudu Wireless kit costs $80.  What's New: Vudu just added the Web-based music application Pandora to its collection of more than 120 Web-based video content channels, which already includes Picasa, YouTube and Flickr.  Roku (The Middle Child)  What It Is: The Roku digital video player, also known as the Netflix Player by Roku, is a box that streams Netflix and Amazon Video On Demand movies over the Internet to your television.  Price: $100.  Rental Fees: Roku requires a Netflix unlimited instant-watch account, which starts at $9. Amazon has both rental and purchase options. Rentals cost about $1 to $4. Purchases run from about $1 for TV shows and about $15 for movies.  Number of Titles: Over 50,000. (About 12,000 from Netflix and 40,000 from Amazon).  The Good: A lot of companies claim their units can be installed by a child. The Roku actually can. I was up and running in three minutes. The "getting started" manual is one of the simplest, most dummy-proof visual guides I've seen. The Roku also comes with built-in Wi-Fi so no adapter is needed and it's extremely compact (5.1 inches by 5.1 inches by 1.6 inches) so it won't hog your living space.  The Bad: The No. 1 gripe is its limited selection. Netflix's Instant Watch option trails Netflix's much larger DVD-by-mail catalog. My Netflix Instant Watch lists 1995's "To Die For" and 1998's "The Waterboy" among its "new" movie releases. By comparison, my new movie releases for the DVD-by-mail option include "Changeling" and "Burn After Reading." I also encountered some buffering delays when I used the fast-forward/rewind controls.  What's New: This summer, Roku will release its software developer's kit for Web video providers, so expect more channels. It will also soon offer ad-supported and free content. The company is looking into online photo and music services.  Boxee (The Youngest Child)  What It Is: This service integrates and creates a single interface for the photos, music and video on your computer's hard drive. Boxee also lets users stream content from Netflix, YouTube, CNN.com and other sites for access on your television.  Price: Free.  The Good: No box needed. Downloads straight onto your desktop. Also good if you enjoy the social-networking aspect of entertainment. Boxee automatically updates your Twitter, Tumblr and FriendFeed accounts and shares your friends' activity so you can follow, recommend and find new content. The service also works on Apple TV and, because it operates on an open-source platform, allows users to personalize what they view by letting them add music and video sites.  The Bad: Have to sit through commercials. For now, Boxee is only compatible with Mac and Linux computers. Another snag: Earlier this month, the free online video service Hulu blocked the Boxee browser from accessing its site. Best case situation? The Hulu block proves to be an isolated incident. Worst case? Other companies follow suit. Also, Boxee works only on content without digital rights management. And the nontechie Boxee user will probably find configuring Linux and Apple TV difficult.  What's New: New alpha version released March 24.
abstract: Making heads and tails of competing video-on-demand products.

headline.main: Vudu, Roku, Boxee: What's the Difference?
headline.print_headline: Vudu, Roku, Boxee: What's the Difference?

"Despite heroic efforts of our emergency-room staff, the child was pronounced dead," at 12:33 p.m., said Dr. Warren B. Licht, the hospital's chief medical officer. "Everything possible was tried to save this child's life."   Eleven other people, both children and adults, sustained minor injuries. Some were taken to New York Downtown Hospital, and others to Bellevue Hospital Center.   When the accident occurred, around 14 children were being led in a "daisy chain" line -- holding onto each other and accompanied by adult chaperons -- along East Broadway from a library visit back to their day care program, the Red Apple Child Development Center, at 25 Market Street, the police said.   The van, a 2000 Ford, was traveling on East Broadway and appeared to make a three-point turn to make a delivery. Shortly after -- witnesses at times gave conflicting accounts -- the van lurched, going in reverse over the curb and onto the sidewalk, according to witnesses.  Early in the day, the police had said that before the accident the van had stopped and the driver had gotten out, and that the vehicle then began to move, without anyone behind the wheel. The police later appeared to retract that account, but by Thursday evening the authorities were again saying that the driver, Chao Fu, 52, had double-parked and entered a store, leaving the van running and in reverse gear, thinking it was in park. Mr. Fu was not charged.   Alma Torres, 49, who was standing across the street from the scene of the accident, said of the driver: "He backed up. He jumped the curb. You heard the bang. People started running." Ms. Torres said she later saw a Chinese woman, distraught and screaming.   Anthony Amoroso, 50, who lives in East New York, Brooklyn, said of the driver: "He was making a three-point turn. He backed up onto the sidewalk." All he heard after that, Mr. Amoroso, was "the screaming."  Another man, Kenneth Martin, 41, of Bushwick, Brooklyn, saw the aftermath of the accident and described seeing a girl being placed in an ambulance. "She was scared," Mr. Martin said. "Her arms were lifted up."   Pamela Leitstein, 48, who is also from East New York, said: "It was chaos." Katharine Montaldo, 39, from the East Village, said: "I heard screaming. I came running up. All I saw was blood."   Police officials said the driver of the truck did not leave the scene of the accident. Witnesses gave varying accounts of the driver's actions after the crash: one said he left the van as if in a state of shock, while another witness that police officers removed the driver from the van.   A silver-gray van with the name of a company, China Chalet, emblazoned on its side was sitting on the sidewalk along the east side of East Broadway on Thursday afternoon.   On the sidewalk, directly behind the van and in front of the building, the police placed cloth sheets across the sidewalk. The sheets were stained with blood; at moments, the wind briefly blew off one of the sheet, revealing the crumpled body of a small child, wearing gray pants.   A woman who answered the phone Thursday afternoon at China Chalet's office, at 47 Broadway, declined to confirm that its truck was involved in the accident, but said in Chinese that "something happened." The woman said the company's owner was not available for comment, and then hung up.   The block of East Broadway where the accident occurred is a crowded commercial corridor, filled with restaurants and food shops at the base of tenement buildings.  At 33 East Broadway, a few doors down from the scene of the accident, is the historic Chatham Square Branch of the New York Public Library. The branch opened in 1903 and was designed by the architectural firm of McKim, Mead and White.   The Red Apple Child Development Center, where the children were enrolled, has two licenses, one for infants and toddlers and one for children 2 to 6 years, according to the Bureau of Child Care at the city's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene.   A woman who answered the phone at the child care center on Thursday afternoon said that the situation was unclear. She said in Chinese, "We don't have any information right now."  At about 2 p.m., a grief-stricken man and woman clutching each other were quickly escorted out of the child-care center by police and into a waiting police van, which sped down the street, sirens blaring. The man and woman did not answer questions from reporters.   Later on Thursday afternoon, Xiaoping Fan, director of the day-care center, said in a statement released by its lawyer, Robert S. Wolf:     All of us at Red Apple Child Development Center are stunned and deeply saddened by this tragic accident. Our hearts go out to the families of all of the children involved and especially to the two families who suffered the loss of their child. We are doing everything possible to provide support to our students, parents, and their loved ones.    The Manhattan borough president, Scott M. Stringer, who went to the scene of the accident, said in a statement afterward that the accident pointed up the need to better protect pedestrians. Mr. Stringer said:   The Zip code in which 38 East Broadway is located had 25 fatalities and 1,149 injuries from 1995 to 2005, more fatalities than any other Manhattan zip code. And the intersection of Essex and Delancey Streets, located just a few blocks from where today's accident occurred, is the third most dangerous location for Manhattan pedestrians. While the city has taken some important steps to manage traffic in Chinatown, including bollards, better lane designations, and other "traffic calming" measures, it is clear that more needs to be done, particularly given the congestion created by the continued closing of Park Row, which has been shut to most traffic since 9/11.  In New York City overall last year some 300 people were killed in traffic accidents -- nearly one person every day -- and hundreds more were injured, with children and the elderly being particularly vulnerable on our congested streets. The city must take a systematic look in every neighborhood at measures like sidewalk bollards and speed bumps, as well as strict traffic enforcement, to make it safer for New Yorkers to walk the streets of their city.  Sewell Chan, David Giambusso, Kirk Semple and Jennifer 8. Lee contributed reporting.
abstract: At least a dozen were also injured when a van plowed into a crowd.

headline.main: 2 Children Killed in Chinatown Crash
headline.print_headline: 2 Children Killed by Van in Chinatown

snippet: Making heads and tails of competing video-on-demand products.
lead_paragraph: As with your friends' children, odds are you've heard about home-media players from Vudu, Roku and Boxee but are still not able to tell them apart. Here's a quick guide to help you get better acquainted.  Vudu (The Oldest Child)  What It Is: A box that lets you rent or buy movies to watch instantly on your television.  Price: $150.  Rental Fees: Renting standard-definition movies costs $1 to $4; high-definition and HDX movies (see below for explanation) cost $4 to $6. Users can also buy TV episodes for $2 and movies from $5 to $20.  Number of Titles: 14,000 movies and TV episodes, including what the company calls "the largest HD library anywhere" with over 1,400 movies.   The Good: Great picture quality, clean user interface and no monthly fee. Vudu delivers actual HD-quality viewing (up to 1080p) and 5.1 Dolby surround sound thanks in part to deals with Lionsgate, Paramount and Universal Studios. Vudu also offers 500 titles in HDX, a video format that has been optimized for 40-inch and larger HDTVs. But be warned: HDX download times are long -- think hours, not minutes. Users can buy movies the same day they're released on DVD.  The Bad: Erases rented movies after 24 hours, after which you have to pay $1 for a one-day extension. No built-in Wi-Fi, but a Vudu Wireless kit costs $80.  What's New: Vudu just added the Web-based music application Pandora to its collection of more than 120 Web-based video content channels, which already includes Picasa, YouTube and Flickr.  Roku (The Middle Child)  What It Is: The Roku digital video player, also known as the Netflix Player by Roku, is a box that streams Netflix and Amazon Video On Demand movies over the Internet to your television.  Price: $100.  Rental Fees: Roku requires a Netflix unlimited instant-watch account, which starts at $9. Amazon has both rental and purchase options. Rentals cost about $1 to $4. Purchases run from about $1 for TV shows and about $15 for movies.  Number of Titles: Over 50,000. (About 12,000 from Netflix and 40,000 from Amazon).  The Good: A lot of companies claim their units can be installed by a child. The Roku actually can. I was up and running in three minutes. The "getting started" manual is one of the simplest, most dummy-proof visual guides I've seen. The Roku also comes with built-in Wi-Fi so no adapter is needed and it's extremely compact (5.1 inches by 5.1 inches by 1.6 inches) so it won't hog your living space.  The Bad: The No. 1 gripe is its limited selection. Netflix's Instant Watch option trails Netflix's much larger DVD-by-mail catalog. My Netflix Instant Watch lists 1995's "To Die For" and 1998's "The Waterboy" among its "new" movie releases. By comparison, my new movie releases for the DVD-by-mail option include "Changeling" and "Burn After Reading." I also encountered some buffering delays when I used the fast-forward/rewind controls.  What's New: This summer, Roku will release its software developer's kit for Web video providers, so expect more channels. It will also soon offer ad-supported and free content. The company is looking into online photo and music services.  Boxee (The Youngest Child)  What It Is: This service integrates and creates a single interface for the photos, music and video on your computer's hard drive. Boxee also lets users stream content from Netflix, YouTube, CNN.com and other sites for access on your television.  Price: Free.  The Good: No box needed. Downloads straight onto your desktop. Also good if you enjoy the social-networking aspect of entertainment. Boxee automatically updates your Twitter, Tumblr and FriendFeed accounts and shares your friends' activity so you can follow, recommend and find new content. The service also works on Apple TV and, because it operates on an open-source platform, allows users to personalize what they view by letting them add music and video sites.  The Bad: Have to sit through commercials. For now, Boxee is only compatible with Mac and Linux computers. Another snag: Earlier this month, the free online video service Hulu blocked the Boxee browser from accessing its site. Best case situation? The Hulu block proves to be an isolated incident. Worst case? Other companies follow suit. Also, Boxee works only on content without digital rights management. And the nontechie Boxee user will probably find configuring Linux and Apple TV difficult.  What's New: New alpha version released March 24.
abstract: Making heads and tails of competing video-on-demand products.

headline.main: Vudu, Roku, Boxee: What's the Difference?
headline.print_headline: Vudu, Roku, Boxee: What's the Difference?

snippet: The third try's the charm for President Obama's appointments to lead the Commerce Department as the Senate confirms the former Washington governor.
lead_paragraph: The third try is, evidently, the charm for President Obama's appointments to lead the Commerce Department. The Senate has just voted to confirm former Gov. Gary Locke of Washington to the post.   Mr. Obama's first two nominees withdrew: Gov. Bill Richardson because of a pay-for-play investigation in his home state of New Mexico, and Senator Judd Gregg, a New Hampshire Republican, over philosophical differences and a dispute about control of the Census Bureau.  But after all that controversy, Mr. Locke breezed through, with the Senate approving his nomination by voice vote. That leaves only one outstanding cabinet appointment: Gov. Kathleen Sebelius of Kansas as Health and Human Services secretary.   Senator Patty Murray, Democrat from his home state, extolled his credentials and his background tonight in endorsing him for the post. "Governor Locke understands the importance of the American dream because he has lived it. His grandfather emigrated from China and worked as a servant just one mile from the governor's mansion in Olympia that his grandson would one day call home."  She also recalled a situation where he grilled her about legislation she was championing when she was in the state Senate and he was chairman of the appropriations committee.  In addition, Ms. Murray cited issues confronting the global economy, like climate change, and said: "One of the most critical jobs the Commerce Secretary performs is finding markets for American products and technologies. Governor Locke understands how important this is – and he knows how to do it successfully. As the two-term governor of the nation's most trade-dependent state, he spent eight years breaking down trade barriers and promoting our American products – from airplanes, to apples, to operating systems. He has led numerous, successful delegations to our Asian trading partners to help build those relationships."
abstract: The third try's the charm for President Obama's appointments to lead the Commerce Department as the Senate confirms the former Washington governor.

headline.main: Locke Confirmed as Commerce Secretary
headline.print_headline: Locke Confirmed as Commerce Secretary

snippet: As the baseball season begins, Major League Baseball is hoping to sell fans on new ways to follow their teams online.
lead_paragraph: (Photo:  Viewers can watch a video demo of baseball games at MLB.com. )   The 2009 Major League Baseball season starts today, which for fans of franchises like the Chicago Cubs, Kansas City Royals and my own hapless Cleveland Indians, means it's time for our annual dose of extended aggravation. Fortunately, Major League Baseball has provided new ways to administer the pain. We covered some of the changes in February, but here's a refresher:  MLB.TV. For an $80 season-pass, fans can watch real-time video of games outside their home media market (so New-York-area residents, for example, cannot use this to watch Yankees or Mets games on their computers.) A new premium version of the software, available for $110, offers high-definition video and a DVR-like function that lets subscribers rewind and watch the highlights. A feature called audio sync lets fans overlay their favorite radio broadcasters onto the television feed. This year, MLB is streaming games in Adobe Flash, after dumping Microsoft's Silverlight technology last year.   MLB.com At Bat 2009 for the iPhone and iPod Touch: Now available in the Apple App store for $9.99, the application offers a pitch-by-pitch game tracker, video highlights of games and Gameday Audio, which lets fans listen to live audio broadcasts of every game without any blackout restrictions. This is one way I'll be following the season--I evidently haven't learned my lesson from past Tribe disappointments--and I'm curious to measure the performance of the audio stream on AT&T's 3G network.  MLB.com Mobile Premium for BlackBerry. Available for BlackBerry Storm, Bold and Curve 8900 for $14.99 for the entire season. Much like the iPhone App, it offers Gameday Audio, pitch-by-pitch tracking, and video highlights. MLB says versions for other BlackBerry models are coming soon.
abstract: As the baseball season begins, Major League Baseball is hoping to sell fans on new ways to follow their teams online.

headline.main: Play Ball! Opening Day on the Web

snippet: Dell’s new Adamo laptop is slim and pricey, but is the timing off?
lead_paragraph: Call your product "the world's thinnest," and the line begins to form. In theory.  Dell's just-announced "premium" computer notebook, the Adamo, starts at $2,000 and has the thin cachet. It is the first high-profile competition for the MacBook Air from Apple.  (Photo:  )   The Adamo, the subject of much speculation last year and a rather funky, if somewhat surreal, Dell demonstration at the Consumer Electronics Show in January, is 0.65 inches at its thickest point, with its guts wedged into a single piece of aluminum (did we mention MacBook?) and weighs about four pounds, about a pound more than the Air.  Adamo, which will ship later in March, is a brand as well as a piece, Dell says, and today's entry is billed as a flagship model, which means lower-priced laptops are most likely in the pipeline. You'll find all the usual component suspects here, including an Intel Core 2 Duo SU9300 processor running at 1.2GHz (fairly pedestrian performance for two large, I think), 2 gigabytes of RAM and a 128-gigabyte solid-state drive, in keeping with the current fashion for thin notebooks. Also, two USB 2.0 ports, one combo USB/eSATA port, a DisplayPort output and Bluetooth/Wi-Fi.  Want an optical drive? There's none on board. It's an option, as is a Tumi carry-bag.  "Great design needs to be timeless and evoke emotion in people," Alex Gruzen, senior vice president of Dell's consumer products, said in a statement. "While a premium computing experience was assumed for Adamo, the intent was for people to see, touch and explore Adamo and be rewarded by the select materials and craftsmanship you would expect in a fine watch."  Well, the Adamo does tell time. But it's facing economic headwinds -- the MacBook Air has struggled to find an audience — at a time when thrifty might trump fashionable, certainly in the laptop arena. And the Mac is less ($1,799) with a faster chip. Still, if you want a Rolex, you want a Rolex.
abstract: Dell’s new Adamo laptop is slim and pricey, but is the timing off?

headline.main: Dell Unveils Thin Laptop
headline.print_headline: "Thinner": The Sequel

snippet: A few weeks ago, while researching a story on abalone farming in California, I got a lesson in how to clean and cook the West Coast mollusk at Manresa restaurant in Los Gatos (a k a Silicon Valley). Manresa is too far off the radar to rate with mo...
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, while researching a story on abalone farming in California, I got a lesson in how to clean and cook the West Coast mollusk at Manresa restaurant in Los Gatos (a k a Silicon Valley). Manresa is too far off the radar to rate with most food writers, who tend to stick to San Francisco and Yountville, but its chef, David Kinch, is doing some exciting things — some of which I write about in next Wednesday’s Dining section.
abstract: A few weeks ago, while researching a story on abalone farming in California, I got a lesson in how to clean and cook the West Coast mollusk at Manresa restaurant in Los Gatos (a k a Silicon Valley). Manresa is too far off the radar to rate with most food writers, who tend to stick to San Francisco and Yountville, but its chef, David Kinch, is doing some exciting things — some of which I write about in next Wednesday’s Dining section. While most chefs today focus on plating carefully constructed (or deconstructed) dishes, in several instances Kinch has gone in the opposite direction, sending out “natural,” borderline chaotic-looking food.  The Tide Pool in which my abalone appeared looked like what you’d scoop up in a rocky puddle near the ocean: pieces of seafood, abalone, sea urchin and its roe in a clear broth made from kombu, white soy sauce and an infusion of shiitake mushrooms. No visible fussing in the bowl — or perhaps endless fussing rendered invisible. A dessert of peanut mousse wasn’t stacked or sauce-squiggled or pretty in any way. The components were put on the plate in a haphazard fashion that could only be intentional. It was clever and kind of punk, a Pavement of the plate. While it might have looked messy to the people dining around me — about as stylized as a Moosewood stir-fry — I was strangely excited by the shift, which I have yet to see elsewhere.

headline.main: Now Serving | The Opposite of Fussy

snippet: Before he was the Knicks’ best threat off the bench, and before he was a basketball star at the University of Washington, Nate Robinson was a football player.
lead_paragraph: Before he was the Knicks’ best threat off the bench, and before he was a basketball star at the University of Washington, Nate Robinson was a football player  a cornerback, to be precise, who excelled through high school and originally went to college on a football scholarship. Robinson, whose father, Jacque, was a running back at Washington, played one season for the Huskies before walking on for their basketball team and quitting football. But when Pacific-10 Conference teams are playing in bowl games, Robinson cannot help but sneak a peek, despite not being a fan of the Bowl Championship Series system. JOSHUA ROBINSON

snippet: What to do and where to go if your laptop's monitor cracks up.
lead_paragraph: Is a cracked laptop screen worth fixing?  A damaged LCD screen is typically one of the more expensive things to replace on a laptop computer. With parts and labor, it could cost north of $500 to get the screen replaced, but you should weigh the worthiness of the repair with other factors like the age and overall condition of the computer. If you opt to have a professional service replace the screen, shop around for estimates.  There are also several types of repair options available. If you prefer to drop the wounded computer off to live humans, the Geek Squad (anchored in most Best Buy stores) is among the companies that replace LCD screens.  If you have another computer to use as a backup and can go without the broken one for a while, an online mail-in repair shop might offer lower prices. The Spare Parts Warehouse, for example, does PC laptop repairs, while iResQ specializes in Mac laptops and other Apple hardware. Most online services list repair prices or have online forms you can use to request an estimate. LCDs4Less also specializes in replacement laptop screens.   If you're feeling technically adept and adventurous, you can also buy just the replacement screen from a shop such as ScreenTek and attempt to install it yourself. The Computer Shopper site lists the basic steps of LCD screen replacement, but the procedure may vary by model. ScreenTek also has a YouTube video of the process, it you want a preview of what to expect.  If even the do-it-yourself options are too expensive for you, a new laptop may be the way to go. Thanks to the influx of lightweight, low-cost Netbooks, there are more affordable options than ever before and you can find Windows XP machines for far less than $500.  If you to decide to buy a new laptop, check to see if the place you're buying it from offers free recycling of old computers; Dell is one company that does. If not, delivering the broken laptop to a local recycling center can help keep it out of a landfill.
abstract: What to do and where to go if your laptop's monitor cracks up.

headline.main: Q & A: Weighing a Heavy Laptop Repair
headline.print_headline: Q & A: Weighing a Heavy Laptop Repair

snippet: David Kinch Abalone and a dessert of peanut mousse at Manresa in Califo...
lead_paragraph: David Kinch Abalone and a dessert of peanut mousse at Manresa in California.   A few weeks ago, while researching a story on abalone farming in California, I got a lesson in how to clean and cook the West Coast mollusk at Manresa restaurant in Los Gatos (a k a Silicon Valley). Manresa is too far off the radar to rate with most food writers, who tend to stick to San Francisco and Yountville, but its chef, David Kinch, is doing some exciting things — some of which I write about in next Wednesday's Dining section.  While most chefs today focus on plating carefully constructed (or deconstructed) dishes, in several instances Kinch has gone in the opposite direction, sending out "natural," borderline chaotic-looking food.   The Tide Pool in which my abalone appeared looked like what you'd scoop up in a rocky puddle near the ocean: pieces of seafood, abalone, sea urchin and its roe in a clear broth made from kombu, white soy sauce and an infusion of shiitake mushrooms. No visible fussing in the bowl — or perhaps endless fussing rendered invisible.  A dessert of peanut mousse wasn't stacked or sauce-squiggled or pretty in any way. The components were put on the plate in a haphazard fashion that could only be intentional. It was clever and kind of punk, a Pavement of the plate.  While it might have looked messy to the people dining around me — about as stylized as a Moosewood stir-fry — I was strangely excited by the shift, which I have yet to see elsewhere.  "I think the naturalism plating is more in sync with our emphasis on ingredient sourcing, and also trying to get to the essence of these ingredients," said Kinch, who, rather than go to the farmer's market (he'd rather use his mornings to surf), has partnered with nearby Love Apple Farm to grow 80 percent of his ingredients. "Nature is what inspires us, and I like the idea of mimicking nature in part of the presentation." Memo to members of the micromanagement school: time to loosen up.
abstract:
David Kinch Abalone and a dessert of peanut mousse at Manresa in California.
A few weeks ago, while researching a story on abalone farming in California, I got a lesson in how to clean and cook the West Coast mollusk at Manresa restaurant in Los Gatos (a k a Silicon Valley). Manresa is too far off the radar to rate with most food writers, who tend to stick to San Francisco and Yountville, but its chef, David Kinch, is doing some exciting things — some of which I write about in next Wednesday's Dining section. While most chefs today focus on plating carefully constructed (or deconstructed) dishes, in several instances Kinch has gone in the opposite direction, sending out "natural," borderline chaotic-looking food. The Tide Pool in which my abalone appeared looked like what you'd scoop up in a rocky puddle near the ocean: pieces of seafood, abalone, sea urchin and its roe in a clear broth made from kombu, white soy sauce and an infusion of shiitake mushrooms. No visible fussing in the bowl — or perhaps endless fussing rendered invisible. A dessert of peanut mousse wasn't stacked or sauce-squiggled or pretty in any way. The components were put on the plate in a haphazard fashion that could only be intentional. It was clever and kind of punk, a Pavement of the plate. While it might have looked messy to the people dining around me — about as stylized as a Moosewood stir-fry — I was strangely excited by the shift, which I have yet to see elsewhere.
